characters: BACK TO THE OVERHEAD CAMERA. IT HOVERS...HOVERS...AND GOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BODY careening toward the CAMERA. Lurches to a stop, almost falls. Eyes wild, face glazed w sweat.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.0., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: I want to tell you about the time I almost died. Bright magnesium moonlight. Behind the body‘s silhouette: shadow of a country house. HOBBES plunges forward again, veering toward some bushes.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: I never thought it would happen. Not to me. Not at this age. Falls to his knees, dives face-first into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Beaten...outsmarted... Digs under the bushes, clawing dirt like a wild animal, breaking branches, cursing under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (LIVE)
dialogues.text: God damn, God damn, God damn! Digging getting more desperate, manic: he’s searching for something, and it’s life and death. Finally he sees it. Lunges, grabs. Car keys. Pauses to catch his breath. Can‘t. Tries to pull himself up onto all fours. Can’t. Glances toward the car, makes one last effort to rise. Ca Spins, falls onto his back. Hyperventilating. MOVE IN ON FACE: 40, normally handsome, now ravaged, in pain...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: The name is Hobbes. John Hobbes. Most decorated detective on the Chicago police force and all that jazz. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www be  He grabs his chest in pain -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: But all the medals, hard work, ++-Mone of it is worth a damn now. SLOW PAN from him...to the surrounding landscape...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: How did I get in this fix? How did it all begin? Leaves rustle: wind. Supérsaturated moonlight gives every an eerie cast, like a photographic negative. MUSIC emphas a subliminal feeling: we're seein ings which do not exist

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: No, no if I go back to the beginning, it’1ll take forever. Let’s start more recently. Somewhere... Anywhere... (strong, decisive) Here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON. DAWN.
dialogues.text: Hyper-clear image, like a post card. HOLD. INT. PRISON. EXECUTION ROOM. DAWN. Another gleaming stylized image: the chair, polished brig SLOW PAN TO: the ceiling. Hole where the cyanide pellets SMASH CUTS, BANG/BANG/BANG: Ceiling, floor: other holes f poison gas. The chair, waiting. INT. PRISON. CELL. DAWN. EDGAR REESE (30, white, large-bodied, vacant eyes, bald h sits on his bed, legs stretched out casually, hands behin head, twiddling his thumbs at a fantastic speed. A GUARD goes by. Rattlesnake strike: Reese kicks the door

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Hey shithead, where’s Hobbes? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  The Guard walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a man’s hand. He‘s playing with them. Nervous habit. Hobbes. He is: EXT. PRISON. INSIDE THE GATES, SIDE ENTRANCE. DAY. Hobbes stands by the entrance. His boss, MAGUIRE (54, tou smart) is approaching. Behind Maguire, a limo is pulling

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: The Governor? I thought he didn’t approve -

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: The more they don’t approve, the more they want to watch. So what’s this, hotshot, six notches on your belt?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Eight.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: (slightly ironic) Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (friendly) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Ask more nicely, huh? A PRISON AIDE opens the side door, stares blankly at Hobb

dialogues.speaker: PRISON AIDE
dialogues.text: He wants you. Hobbes glances at Maguire, rolls his eyes - INT. PRISON. CELLBLOCK. DAWN. A dimly lit cellblock, streaks of light and darkness; the pattern of the bars falls across Hobbes’s face as he walk Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  He slows, stops in deep shadow, looks in at Reese. Reese smiles, indicates Hobbes, talks to someone we Can't

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Well, well. The brilliant detective who sealed my brutish fate. {back to Hobbes) I thought you'd be too cowardly to show. Hobbes sees, in with Reese: a GUY IN A SUIT with a camcor

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Network? As the Guard unlocks the cell to let Hobbes in:

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Some Prison schmoo. For the Governor. The Gov hates capital punishment, wants to make a video record of this vile ceremonial. Says he‘’1ll show it to legislators, but I think he’ll use it for a circle jerk with his dinner guests. (strikes exaggerated pose) My veins bulging... (smiles) It’s good to see you, Hobbes. My best pal. Reese lunges. Grabs Hobbes’ hand, kisses it - Hobbes yanks the hand back in disgust, wipes it off

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Why'd you ask for me?, I’m not a priest.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: No? Reese mutters under his breath. Nonsense syllables of som kind, Fast and unintelligible: a private joke. Hobbes watches, irritated. Reese flies into a pantomime. Grabs the air. Gives Hobbes finger. Rubs palms together. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www Hobbes starts to speak. Reese stops him with a gesture a slides smoothly into words again:

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: You remind me of someone, Hobbes. Indeed you do. Indeedy deed. Do you like riddles? (CONT. }

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Here’s a "beaut": Why is there a space between Lyons and Spakowsky?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Don't you? Open your eyes, pal. Look around sometime.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Reese. The Express Train, Reese flashes Hobbes a nasty smile, but Hobbes has alread turned back toward the door, toward the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: (suddenly strong, commanding) Before you leave, remember this. (Hobbes turns back) In a day, a week, month. Remember: (Speaks in a foreign tongue) ,

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: German?

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: (mocking) Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: What goes around...really goes around. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  INT. PRISON. VIP VIEWING ROOM. DAY. VIPs are assembled, silent, nervous. How to behave at an execution? The room is rectangular, with a one-way mirror the long wall: looks into the execution room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock reads: 7:57. The Prison Aide with the Camcorder is at one end of the r best vantage point. The WARDEN and the GOVERNOR are exchanging whispers. Hobbes stands with Maguire. Hobbes fiddies with his quart Everyone's head turns: Reese is being led into the execution room by TWO GUARDS. Hypervigilant. Casing the room, the chair, one-way mirror He spreads his arms wide, facing the mirror; we hear perf

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Howdy, ladies. Gents. Cocksuckers and pederasts... He slows his entrance, blowing kisses toward the mirror..

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Hope you like the show... (another kiss) Hello Gov, my love.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (irritated, to WARDEN) He’s certainly enjoying himself.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Since he’s been in, he’s started a fire, a riot, and founded a KKK unit. We're very pleased to see him graduate. The Guards strap Reese into the chair, securing his hands feet. Another Guard, a REDHEAD, is watching... When the first two Guards retreat, the Redhead steps forw checks everything. As the Redhead leaves, his hand trails casually up Reese' arm... Reese is smiling. His lips seem to be moving... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  7 The Redhead enters a cubicle at the end of the room, glan at the clock: 7:59. He sits behind a small monitor, and w realize: this is the executioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sound is coming from Reese -

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: What’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PRISON AIDE
dialogues.text: He’s... I believe he’s singing, sir. Reese increases his volume; the old Rolling Stones song:

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: "Time...is on my side... Yes, it is. Time...is on my side... You know it is... (etc.) His singing becoming more raucous, inappropriate... The VIPs getting more uncomfortable. Not the solemn spect they'd anticipated. Sweep second hand on the clock getting closer to the 12, to 8:00 a.m. Reese sings loud and wild; a maniac with good pipes:

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: “I’11 come runnin’ back... I'll come runnin’ back... The Redhead is staring at the Warden, waiting for the oka The Governor, enraged by the singing, elbows the Warden: The Warden nods: Yes, yes, but not until... He waits, wai The second hand hits the 12 - Warden nods. The Redhead throws the switch - Pellets clatter down - A cloud of cyanide gas billows - Reese holds his breath, bulging cheeks, as the gas rises, sensuous and deadly, around him. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  Turns toward his audience. Last grin. Gives ‘em the finger - Violently sucks in the poison. His body shakes - Faces of the Observers. Repelled, excited, transfixed... After a long moment, their expressions change. Shocked aftermath. It's over so fast. Reese’s body. Slumped. The CAMERA MOVES across it as if t say, subtly: something is still happening. We come to res HIS LEFT HAND. A final muscular twitch, just the pinkie.. OVERHEAD SHOT, TIGHT ON REESE, collapsed in his chair. In odd effect, SOUND becomes distant, muted. The CAMERA RISES TO THE CEILING AND MOVES.... Over to the Warden, chatting with the Governor. It hovers over him, t MOVES AGAIN, over the Governor himself, lingers... ...and slides away, out of the room... ...into the next room, the Executioner‘’s cubicle. The CAMERA ARCS DOWN onto the Redhead's face. SOUND eases to normal. The Redhead‘s jotting a few notes. For the fir time we get a good look at him: 28, boyish, efficient. The Warden sticks his head in the door:

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: You okay, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (REDHEAD)
dialogues.text: {hint of admiration) Never saw one sing before. For the Governor's sake, the Warden acts like a good guy:

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Take the rest of the day off, huh? The Warden closes the door and Jimmy smiles to himself. S at the door. Hold this 1/2 second too long - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  EXT. PRISON. MORNING. Maguire and Hobbes walking to their cars.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you even come, Hobbes. I gotta hold hands with the Suits, but - (you could)

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: The scum we see day to day?, they never accept consequences. Beat somebody up, rob somebody, kill somebody; somehow or other it ain’t their fault. This is the consequence of what I do; I gotta be here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: (dry, friendly) This ain’t your fault. Hobbes smiles, appreciating it, gives Maguire a friendly with the back of his hand. As Hobbes gets into his’ car: THE CAMERA PANS. Driving slowly toward them in an old convertible is Jimmy, the Redheaded Executioner. As he pa he gives them a casual glance. Contrary to what we expect The CAMERA MOVES AWAY, with him, as he sings to himself:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE EXECUTIONER
dialogues.text: Not for just an hour... Not for just a day... Not for just a year, but always, all the time... Just a beautiful summer morning and a happy guy who got o work early. cuT TO: EXT. SUBURBAN MALL. DAY. Gorgeous day. Jimmy drives into the parking lot, parks in handicapped spot. INT. SUBURBAN MALL. DAY. The mall's just opening; a smattering of people. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  10 From an OVERHEAD ANGLE we watch Jimmy stroll along, whist MUSIC tells us, subtly: something odd is happening. Jimmy stops, buys a bagel and walks on, eating it. As he walks, his hand brushes casually against a BUSINESS coming the other way. The CAMERA EXECUTES A 20 DEGREE REVERSE TURN, FOLLOWS the Businesswoman. Crisp efficient walk. After a few steps: She touches a SMALL BOY, holding his MOTHER’s hand. We FOLLOW the Mother and Boy. They wander slowly, looking store windows, chatting... The Mother's shoulder bumps ag a thin ANOREXIC MAN with a scruffy beard. The Mother and Boy move on. We HOLD on the Anorexic Man a stops, looks around...stands up a little straighter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facing the Anorexic Man. Thin smile. He checks his watch. Walks into a PET STORE. The MIDDLE-AGED OWNER is opening

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED OWNER
dialogues.text: You're late, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES THE ANOREXIC
dialogues.text: Fuck your booty with a garden hose.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED OWNER
dialogues.text: {completely stunned) What did you - (say?)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES THE ANOREXIC
dialogues.text: You're an imbecile, you reek like a rhesus, and your wife is boffing that moron who runs the cookie shop.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED OWNER
dialogues.text: Charles, I hate to do this, but

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES THE ANOREXIC
dialogues.text: Put the job where the hose goes. He walks out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  i INT. CHICAGO BAR. NIGHT. Lively scene, ethnic neighborhood. In the back is a table off-duty cops: Hobbes, LOU (half-Jewish, half-Italian, 40 jaded extrovert), TIFFANY (black, 28, totally one of the LAWRENCE (35, bland), and JONESY (55, Hobbes’ partner: th ultimate cop, a worker, a bear in polyester).

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (What I don’t get is)...this cockamamie three strikes thing.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: If it was me, I'd make it Lucky Strikes. (puffing her cigarette) Arrest ‘em, give ‘em a cigarette, ‘n’ shoot ‘em,

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Not a bad idea. Just... (waving away a cloud) ...blow your smoke the other way, huh Tiff? A WAITRESS has come to their table -

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: {slight flirt, to Waitress) Hey, Gracie. (to others) So whatta we got here? Three Heinekens... (turns to Jonesy)

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Becks dark.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (to Hobbes) Hotshot? Hobbes and Jonesy are the only non-regulars. Jonesy usual works late; Hobbes is here celebrating Reese's execution.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: A Bud.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: A Bud? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  12

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: What, you can’t afford imported? I‘ll treat.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I can afford -

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: At least get a Bud Ice, huh? (as Hobbes shakes his head) Bud Lite? Bud Extra Dry? Lou is baiting Hobbes, but Hobbes won’t bite, won’t desce that level. He just gives a straightforward answer:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: It’s just a Bud, Lou, okay? She leaves, irritated with Lou for wasting her time. Lou, has fantasies of side action with Gracie, is unhappy to i her disfavor and becomes further annoyed at Hobbes.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You're an unusual cop, Hobbes. Hobbes shrugs as Tiffany pipes in, not at all where Lou w going:

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Yeah, for one thing, he takes crime personally.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: That‘s right. No one kills anybody on my watch.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Oh man. Lou What're you talking? The city is your watch. People kill each other on the hour. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That‘’s what I mean. I gotta do something about it. Half a joke on himself...but also half serious. ANOTHER ANGLE. MINUTES LATER. Gracie finishes serving their beers. Lou is still staring Hobbes, considering whether to raise a certain subject... Lou Let me ask you something, Hobbes. (after Gracie leaves) I've only been (in) your precinct ten weeks, but they say you never take cream, is that true? Hobbes shrugs -

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Come on, you can tell me: true or not?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don't like cream.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: So that means no?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: "No" as in "No, never"? or “No" as” in "Rarely," or "No" as in you do it but you don’t talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Hobbesy. This is Chicago. We got a tradition to uphold...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: What's a matter, your ears don’t work? The man says something, he says it. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  14

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (calmly, to Lou) I have a bed, roof, car. When I'm hungry, I eat. I meet a nice girl, I can afford to take her out. What else do I need?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: A life. Lou So. Hypothetical. Other cops, who have families -

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hobbes has a family. Sort of -

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (pushing on) Other cops, who do feel the need once in a while, (to) skim a little something on the side -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don't judge.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I see. You don’t. judge. (under his breath) He‘s a fucking saint. (aside, to Tiffany) You got any thorns?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: I left ‘em home.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don’t let anybody else judge either, not around me, ‘cause you take any cop on the force, bad or good, cream or no, 99% of the time he’s still doing his job, right?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Ninety-nine five. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, point 5S. So he - {to Tiffany, equal time) or she - is still doing more good every single day than any lawyer, stockbroker, insurance salesman, or US President does in a lifetime. Lou stares at Hobbes. He really didn’t expect this last opinion. Let alone:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Cops are the chosen people. It's hard to tell which way Lou's gonna go on this. Final

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I’m switching to Bud. Meaning: Hobbes is okay. Lou grabs the passing Waitress:

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Hey, Gracie, bring me a Bud, huh? (to others) Anybody else want to go American?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. HIS BEDROOM. NIGHT. Hobbes sleeps. Phone rings. He blinks, shakes his head, answers it:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: ‘Lo? Silence on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (mutters to himself Oh fuck. Hello? Still no response. He hangs up, takes the receiver off the hook and sets it next to his beeper. Then he unplugs the receiver cord so the line’ll be busy but no annoying sound will emit. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  16 He takes a drink of water, shakes his head: he’s awake no He climbs out of bed in his t-shirt and boxers. INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. HALL. NIGHT. He walks down the hall. The door into the next bedroom is open, and a small Nightlite shines. Hobbes pushes the door farther open, looks in: Two beds, a single and a double. The single has been slep in but is empty. In the double are Hobbes’ brother ART, a Art’s son SAM, 8, curled up together. Sweetest thing you ever saw. INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. KITCHEN. DAY. Sam is devouring his cereal. Hobbes sits with, drinking coffee. Art’s at the counter, proudly packing Sam’s lunch

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Here we go: milk, pretzels, apple, peanut butter and jelly sandwich - Simultaneous with this last phrase, Sam says under his br

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Peanut butter and jelly sandwich. (still quietly) Uncle John, will you please make my lunch tomorrow? (as Hobbes nods) I can’t eat the same thing every - A bicycle horn honks repeatedly. Hobbes looks out the win sees: TOBY, 9, on his bike. .

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: There’s Toby! And with Art‘s childish enthusiasm, we suddenly get it: A little retarded. Sam leaps up from the table, grabs a small bookbag and th lunch, gives his father a big hug, the irritation of a mo ago totally forgotten: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  17

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I love you, Dad. Sam heads toward his bike, standing by the front door -

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, don't forget - Sam tears back toward Hobbes, leaps - Hobbes catches him in the air. Sam gives him a tight bear and we sense: Hobbes as second parent. Sam jumps down, sprints to his bike and wheels it out the which Art holds open. Art calls after him, part of the ri

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Have a good day at school! Art closes the door, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What a kid. Come here, Art. (pats chair) Have breakfast with me. “ART You're not in a hurry or something?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Reese is dead, (so) I can relax, go in late for once. Art is pleased: he rarely has time alone with Hobbes. Art comes to the table, readies his breakfast, speaks shyly:

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: I love you, Johnny. . Hobbes smiles wistfully. It’s almost painful that his bro can hit this simple emotional level so naturally, gracefu

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: You ever think it would be easier... your life would be so much easier or something if Sam and I -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Maybe Marcy wouldn’t have - (left) Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  18

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Art. Marcy was a jerk for leaving me. You’re my brother. Sit down, huh? Art sits, dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I love you too. Art smiles, brighter than any sunrise. ANOTHER ANGLE. TIGHT ON A CORNFLAKES BOX. Was cornflakes on the table be As THE CAMERA PULLS BACK we see we are now: INT. ANOTHER APARTMENT. MORNING. Charles the Anorexic sits eating a bowl of cornflakes. Er posture, slightly formal manner. Before he was casually dressed, now he’s in a suit. Incongruous with his present appearance, the apartment ar him is in disarray: books strewn, furniture knocked over: it was recently the scene of an enormous struggle. On the wall beside Charles, out of focus, something is sc in magic marker. Charles sets his spoon in the bowl. He looks down. There are four - and only four - objects o table: cornflakes, milk carton, sugar bowl, and, in the c the bowl of half-eaten cereal. He adjusts the angle of the cornflakes box, moves the mil carton slightly. The four objects now form an odd and distinctive configur like Stonehenge. INT. BATHROOM. DAY. Charles is carefully applying Crest to his toothbrush. St to brush. THE CAMERA BEGINS TO MOVE... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  19 His technique is just like the dentist teaches: small cir along the gum line. The toothpaste foams. His face is blank. He‘s certainly doing a very thorough j those teeth. Behind him we see the window, the bathtub... something sticking out of the tub - A MAN’S FOOT - SHOCK MOVE: THE CAMERA SWOOPS DOWN to the BODY. Eyes open terrified; mouth twisted. HOLD on the horror...then back Charles carefully rinses his toothbrush and leaves the ro INT. APARTMENT. DAY. Charles exits the bathroom, walks to the door, opens it. Turns to examine the apartment. Everything just as he wants it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, we watch Hobbes park his car. Get out. Walk into the precinct. REVERSE ANGLE. Charles The Anorexic stands near a phone booth, watching Hobbes, twirling a fat cigar like a self-satisfied mafios Takes a little puff. cuT TO: INT. PRECINCT. DAY. Hobbes doing paperwork. (HOBBES’ DESK is very clean. Only few objects: carefully, almost geometrically, placed.) Jonesy’s messy desk is on one side of Hobbes, he’s also working. On the other side, Tiffany is listening to a SECRETARY-TYPE (33, spectacular nails, big hair). Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  20

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY TYPE
dialogues.text: He threatens me?, fine. He hits me?, I can deal. But how can you tell, Officer? If one day, no warning, he’s gonna really do it? Hobbes looks at the woman, pondering this question, as hi phone rings. Quick draw:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: John Hobbes. CHARLES’ VOICE Hey, pal, got a pen?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Who's this? CHARLES’ VOICE 17197 South Kedzie, Apartment 12C.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: {jotting it down, bored) What’s there? CHARLES’ VOICE A clue, Magoo. The line goes dead. Hobbes hangs up the phone, considers. Turns to Jonesy:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Couldn’t sleep last night.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Who can?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Remember Reese used to call two, three a.m?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (tease) He loved you, Hobbes, he truly did. That kind of devotion -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I had another call last night. Jonesy raises an eyebrow, wondering... Hobbes flicks the piece of paper with the address. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  21

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yo, Tiff, see if we got a car near 17197 South Kedzie, huh? (gives her the paper) 12C. Have the landlord let ‘em in if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Hot tip?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Probably some bozo saw my name in the Trib, wants to impress his girl. As Tiffany goes off with the slip of paper -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MUSKAVICH’S APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY. An unmarked police car pulls up, Hobbes and Jonesy get ou hurry into the building - INT. BATHROOM. DAY. Hobbes and Jonesy looking at the naked man’s body in the bathtub. A most unpleasant sight.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (reading from notes) Muskavich. Russian expatriate, unemployed electrician. No family, no friends, no enemies.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Everybody’s got enemies. What’s the cause of death?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) (We need an) Autopsy. He points to the number 7 spray-painted on the man’s ches

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What’s this (mean), it’s the killer’s seventh victim?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (leaving bathroom) I guess. We better check the m.o. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  22 INT. APARTMENT. DAY. The place crawls with Cops, Coroners, etc. Hobbes and Jon walk to the table, look at the breakfast stuff: the Mini- Stonehenge configuration of objects. Stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (joke) Looks like your desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (gives Jonesy a look) Whose eats? Meaning the cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Killer. Body’s cold 18 hours, (but the) milk’s not spoiled.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (incredulous) He killed this guy, slept here, had a quiet breakfast and left?

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY
dialogues.text: Seems like. (sees something) Hey check this. He‘s looking at the magic-marker writing on the wall. Hobbes turns. Stares. His blood runs cold as ice. Written on the wall in a cursive scrawl: Lyons
Spakowsky Hobbes continues to stare...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: What? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  23 Hobbes shakes his head, finally finds what's left of his

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: It’s a riddle. Something Reese asked.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: In his cell before he died, Reese asked me: "Why is there a space between Lyons and Spakowsky?" On Hobbes‘ face: INT. PRECINCT. DAY. Maguire stands at Hobbes’ desk looking at photos of the w from Muskavich’s wall. He lowers them, shakes his head:

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Reese had an accomplice?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Fuck us all, Mack. Maguire walks off as Jonesy hangs up the phone, turns to Hobbes:

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Fingerprint. The perp didn’t wear gloves. Left prints on the spoon, cereal bowl, toothbrush. It’s like he's advertising.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Must be he’s not in the databank. Jonesy nods agreement. Lou walks by headed for the FAX. H overhead their conversation; says in his arrogant way:

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I hate to be stupid, huh? (CONT.) Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  24

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Enjoy it, Lou - Lou glares back. Jonesy is sassing him because of the lip gave Hobbes in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But is motive still something we ask here?, or are all crimes just done for their own sake, out of sickness?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: (mimes hitting buzzer) Bzzzz. Number 2.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (off-hand, as always) Everything has motive. Sickness is a motive too. This thought hovers for a moment - In the b.g., SCHWAB (a trainee with an earring and spiky is distributing burritos. Lou picks up from the FAX machi something for him, something for Hobbes and Jonesy. He re theirs on his way over, drops it off on Hobbes’ desk: Lou Look sharp, Bud. (he now calls Hobbes "Bud" because of his beer choice) Coroner’s prelim on the Roosky. Isn’t this that wacko poison Reese used on those Arabs? Hobbes examines the FAX with concern. Lou is right. Schwab reaches Hobbes’ desk with the burritos.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: Chicken, spicy with onions? Hobbes looks up at Schwab. Nods absentmindedly.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey Schwab, you're hip, right?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: Hip, thigh, and crotch. Schwab glances around nervously to see if anyone else hea this un-trainee like remark. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  25

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Tell me this: why is there a space between Lyons and Spakowsky? Schwab stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: I don’t know, man. That’s not a hip query. Hobbes looks around. Everyone’s stopped to eat their burr

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Tiff, you like puzzles and shit, brainteasers?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Long as I'm doing the teasing...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Why is there a space between Lyons and Spakowsky? Beat. She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: What’s that even mean, man? Hobbes shakes his head: he doesn’t know. A lingering beat...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We had a Lyons once. What an asshole. Hobbes turns toward Jonesy, who’s chomping away...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Not your Lyons. This guy was a cop. Hobbes gestures, keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I tell you: he was the King Kong of assholes. I’m talking legend, huh? His name is on the fuckin’ wall. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  26 Hobbes blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonesy leads Hobbes down the dingy back halls of the stat (Here, as elsewhere: small areas which are poorly lit giv spooky sense, as though something is lurking there.)

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Some chief in the 30s thought it'd boost morale... I think they kept with it till ‘75 or...(so), it got like a booby prize. He stops in front of an old metal plaque with an ornate c and the words: FOR OUTSTANDING AND COURAGEOUS VALOR.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Remember? It was out front till they went with the remodel. (CONT.) Jonesy runs a flashlight down the names. In bronze:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE LYONS
dialogues.text: 1965 (blank, but with a residue of old solder. A name was once here, but has been removed.)

dialogues.speaker: ANTON SPAKOWSKY
dialogues.text: Hobbes stares at the plaque.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You musta passed it a thousand times-

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (Yeah.) Right out in the lobby. (quoting Reese) I just had to “open my eyes, look around sometime."

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: I don’t know Spakowsky, but Lyons was so mean his wife finally shot him in a foot. Son of a bitch couldn’t get disability -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Jonesy. Why is there a space here? Who is ‘65? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no clue, man. Not a clue, not @ memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes has just asked Maguire the same question. Maguire up at him with a clear honest face:

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: "65? I don’t know, Hobbes, that was before my time. Hobbes stares at him.... Maguire stares back, then lowers his eyes. He’s lying. He does know something.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Maguire...you know I’1ll find out.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Then find out. Cdd. He doesn’t care if Hobbes knows, he just can’t tell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes sits at this desk. Only a few objects: computer, address book on the corner, etc. He’s on line, going through old issues of the Chicago Tri He's found a front-page article with a photograph of Geor Lyons and a headline: "LYONS NAMED COP OF THE YEAR FOR 19 He looks at the top of the page, the date: February 12, 1 He presses SEARCH and types in: February 12, 1966. The 1966 front page pops up. He searches it: nothing. Hits two keys, gets the front page for February 11, searc that one: nothing. ON HIS FACE as he tries more front pages, without success Then he stops. Moves closer to the screen as he reads - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  28 Headline: ITALIAN DETECTIVE COP OF THE YEAR 1965. Robert Milano nabbed "Kiddo Killer" The photograph shows a handsome man with an honest face, blue uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes presses SEARCH and types in "Robert Milano." The screen says "Searching..." An article pops up about Milano making another arrest. Hobbes scans it quickly, hits SEARCH again. The name "Rob Milano" reappears, and Hobbes hits Return... He waits...waits... Something comes up. He stares. The eerie computer light flickering over his f He hits: PRINT. Paces in front of his window. Goes to the printer, picks up the printed page, reads it as he continues pacing... EXT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. NIGHT. From across the street, we see Hobbes pacing in his windo He is being watched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning coffee cups; Hobbes has come in first thing. He's waving the page he printed from the 1966 Chicago Tribune:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Six months after he’s named Cop of the year, he goes to Canada and blows his brains out. But the article on the suicide is page nine, somebody buried iti (CONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  23

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (slaps print-out) And there’s no information here ‘cept Milano was on suspension at the time. What gives, Maguire?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: It’s old laundry.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I gather, and dirty, but I need this, okay? For a guy who’s out killing people right now, and he’s telling me, right now, by writing on the fucking wall, that I should look at what happened to Milano! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I can’t help you, Hobbes.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I request access to our reports on the suicide - MAGUIRE (overlapping) Get real, huh? I said I can’t - Pissed, Hobbes turns to go -

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I got something else though. (holds up videotape) Reese. From the prison.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (slight sarcasm) Thanks, Maguire. You're a white man. He takes the tape and leaves. FOLLOW HIM OUT into: INT. PRECINCT. MAIN ROOM. DAY. Hobbes comes out, goes by Jonesy’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Tape on Reese, wanna view? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  30

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: You know I hate video.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Anything on Muskavich?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Fingerprints are a bust. All we got is: (consults notes) Killer's tall, left-handed -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (idle, no significance:) Like Reese -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And his teeth are bad.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (Shit.) He bit Muskavich? Hobbes reaches his desk, puts down the tape. In his other hand, he’s still holding the page he printed from the newspaper. He looks at it, picks up the phone, dials 411.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: This is Debra, what city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clipping. At the bottom: "Detective Milano is survive his wife, Sylvia,35, and daughter Gretta, 8 months old."

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Chicago. Sylvia Milano. M-I-L-A-N-O. BACK TO SCENE. Maguire is crossing. Hobbes calls to him, slightly nasty:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey, Lieutenant? This silence on Milano. Is it your own idea, or are you "just following orders?" Maguire stops in his tracks: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  31

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Look. Somebody promised somebody something a long time ago. I’m keeping that promise, huh? Hobbes thinks about this as Maguire moves away and:

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, there’s no such listing.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks. (starts to hang up, then:) Wait. What about... Are you there? (examines clipping) You have a Gretta Milano?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (stands; to Hobbes) Okay, I'll watch. Hobbes tosses him the videotape -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You know, I been thinking -

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: {as to a horse) Whoa, easy boy... OPERATOR’S VOICE Please hold for the number. Hobbes jots down the number as Jonesy comes over:

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Whoever killed Muskavich knows the poison Reese used, he’s quoting Reese... He could be a cop.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (as he dials Gretta’s number) I've thought of that. (points jokingly at Lou)

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA'S VOICE, (FROM PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi. Please leave a message. Beep - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  32

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Ah. John Hobbes. 845-9594. It’s important. He hangs up, and they walk off:

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: You're giving your home number?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don’t know why, I...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: What is it, some girl with a cute voice? Hobbes playfully cuffs Jonesy...but Jonesy is right, Hobb liked her voice - cuT TO: INT. POLICE PRECINCT. VIDEO ROOM. DAY. On screen (from a different angle than before): Reese is singing, wild and raucous:

dialogues.speaker: " REESE
dialogues.text: I‘1l come running back...baby baby I'll come runnin’ back...to you...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Used to have a lounge act, huh? (as Hobbes rewinds tape) You don’t want to watch him get gassed, make sure he’s kaput?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I gotta see this priest again. He presses PLAY. The tape runs: Inside Reese's cell, a scene we haven’t seen before. A PR is talking to the Guard, trying to get the door unlocked. Reese mutters something 0.S. and the CAMERA PANS to him..

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: (quiet, deadly) Father. (You) Step in here, I'll kill you. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  33

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t really mean that -

dialogues.speaker: . REESE
dialogues.text: Five seconds. (is all it‘d take) This registers on the Priest’s face. Reese is calm, motionless, homicidal. THE CAMERA PANS to the Priest, hesitating. The Priest looks at the Guard, who shrugs. CAMERA PANS BACK AND FORTH on this primitive game of chic Reese staring. Priest staring back, trying to make a judgement. Reese gestures with his hand: come on in, dude... Priest still staring... He blinks. Lost it. Turns, speaks softly to the Guard, and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: Coward! (yells after Priest) How can you serve God if you ain’t got any balls?! (flat, to CAMERA) Make sure Hobbes gets a copy of this, huh? - (diff voice) Johnny boy, you watching? (waves at camera) I hope you're paying close attention ...every gesture, every word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly Reese shuts down. Freaky sight: live to dead in seconds. Eyes closed. Motionless. End of scene. Hobbes fast-forwards, to his own entrance, and beyond -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Hold a sec. I wanna... He takes the remote, presses PLAY, and we see: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  34

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Open your eyes, pal. Look around - Jonesy presses REVERSE, and the tape rewinds. He presses PLAY again, and we see Reese lunge for Hobbes’ and kiss it. After a moment, Reese begins babbling nonsense syllables, making weird gestures...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: What’s he talking later, Dutch?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: So he says.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: So this is Dutch too?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: {isn’t it obvious:) This is gibberish.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: oh. (beat) You sure on that? Hobbes blinks, wonders... cUuT TO: EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING. TWILIGHT. Fading light. BOYS play stickball in the street. Hobbes sits in his car, laptop on his knees, plugged into car phone. He’s on line, going through old newspaper file stories on Robert Milano. He glances idly up at a window, starts to look away, then again, more closely... Yes, he did see something. A SHADOW inside. He folds up the laptop. cuT TO: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  35 INT. APARTMENT BUILDING. HALL. EVENING. Hobbes rings the bell. GRETTA (32, beautiful in a glancing way, ethereal but gro a charming casual manner) opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Gretta Milano? She nods v. slightly -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: My name is John Hobbes.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Oh yes. You called. Neither friendly nor stand-offish. She’s just there.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: {flashing badge) May I come in a moment? She looks at his badge, then again at his face. Says noth

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I want to ask about your father. Her face reacts. Here it is, the moment she’s long expect She walks away, leaving the door open for him to follow. INT. GRETTA’S APARTMENT. EVENING. Like a loft, high ceilings. The evening light gives the w walls a soft glow. This effect is intensified by the art massive reproductions of Raphaelite and Pre-Raphaelite an The impact is quite striking, and Hobbes comments:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You’re surrounded by angels.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I teach theology at Northwestern.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: They’re beautiful. He looks at her: she’s beautiful too. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  36

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (soft, neutral) Why do you want to know about my father?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: The files on his case are sealed. She seems to have no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Even now, 30 years later, my boss won't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Good. (considers, then:) Mr. Hobbes, I could tell you what my mother told me before she died.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - (about her death)

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: She’s not. But first I have to ask again: why do you want to know? Is it idle curiosity, or -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: No. See... I’m the guy who caught Edgar Reese, who was just executed -

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Yes, I read about - (him)

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Reese kind of...gave me your father’s name. She looks at him rather blankly, says softly:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Did Reese like to sing? Hobbes nods.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: And at the end, he touched you or -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (slightly spooked) Kissed my hand. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  37 She closes her eyes. When she opens them again, her voice different, more somber:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: You want some coffee? He nods. As she pours coffee for him, gets out milk and s

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: One condition: you and I never spoke. No reports, nothing in the files. My name, and everything I say, is just between us. Is that agreeable? INT. GRETTA’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. MINUTES LATER. They sit with their coffee. She's watching him, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: You look married. He's surprised by the personal remark, but he answers:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Divorced.4 years.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Kids?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: One nephew. Why do you -

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (gentle, efficient) A family man shouldn’t risk it. You believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Just Sundays. My job, seeing what I see, faith isn’t easy to sustain.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (factual) : What you see in your job is nothing. He nods, intrigued...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Risk what? You said "A family man shouldn’t risk -" Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  38

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m thinking that perhaps you‘re here for a purpose you yourself don’t yet see. He starts to respond to this, but before he can get a wor she launches into her story:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: According to my mother, who was admittedly biased, my father was the best cop on the force. Smart, dedicated, incorruptible. He received an award for catching someone named the Kiddo Killer, who was preying on... {there’s more she could say but this will suffice:) ,..small boys. After Kiddo was executed, copy-cat crimes occurred. My father was implicated. The evidence against him mounted: phone calls, fingerprints, witnesses. He went kind of...crazy. Bought a house up in Canada...went there, and shot himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (idly) Can I go up to the house?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (subtly paranoid) Why?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (picking up something) Why not? She nods, taking this under advisement, and proceeds with story:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: The Department told my mother - for the sake of her pension and my father’s good name, all he‘d done for the force - they’d hush it up. I guess they're still keeping their word. Hobbes nods. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  39

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Please understand, Mr. Hobbes, that everyone including my parents saw the evidence against my father and considered it incontrovertible. She leans forward. She looks him right in the eye and spe quietly but with enormous intensity:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But I know - for a fact - that my father was innocent of those crimes.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: How do you know? She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: How do you know he was innocent?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: "Cause I know who did it. And I think you're next, Mr. Hobbes. I'm afraid you’re next. That's all I can tell you. (stands) In fact, that’s more than I can tell you. She walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Wait a second. You were suggesting before that there might be some ether reason I’m here? ~ She gives the slightest of nods as she opens the front do

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Who does? (nods politely) It was nice to meet you. He's thrown by her sudden insistence on getting rid of hi

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Well. If I have further questions, or... Can I at least - (call you) Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  INT. HALL. EVENING.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I’d rather you didn’t. He nods, taken aback again. She starts to close the door, says softly:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Go with God. He stops short, turns - But the door is already closed. cur TO: EXT. STREET. NIGHT. Hobbes parks his car, gets out. Walks down the street lost in thought... (There should be few other pedestrians, not many.)

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Sometimes it seems like the basic job human beings have is to figure out what the hell is going on. (CONT. } Though we don’t pay attention at this point, a MAN is str up the street, toward Hobbes.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Example: Gretta Milano. What was she hiding? What was she afraid of? Why did she end things so abruptly? And her final words, "Go with God," what did they mean? The Man has reached Hobbes. With a chilling shock we recognize: Charles the Anorexic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he passes, he looks Hobbes in the eye - Hobbes looks back - For an instant their eyes lock - On Charles’ face: the hint of a mocking smile - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  They pass each other. Hobbes blinks, a vague apprehension skating across his consciousness... On his back, as he walks away from the camera:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: One never knows, down to the smallest thing. The man who catches your eye in the street. Does he know you? Did you go to high school together, or is he a stranger? Is he a homicidal maniac who hates your guts on sight, or is he thinking about robbing you, or is he (just) some poor creature trying to make a homosexual advance? (CONT .) Charles the Anorexic returns to sight, his back becoming foreground silhouette, as he watches: Hobbes disappears down the dark street.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Or was it nothing, nothing at all?

Art pulls down Sammy's covers, and Hobbes lays the boy in bed. The phone starts ringing again. Art pulls the covers up, smoothes them. Hobbes watches from the doorway.

Charles is at the stove, making himself a grilled-cheese: lonely guy special. The ingredients he’s using are spread the counter in a messy way. He glances at the portable phone sitting in its cradle. I seems to be guilt-tripping him. He picks it up, dials as he cooks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And I'm sorry about it, but... {heading for door) The important thing is: will you please apologize to your husband? MRS. MOOHR’S VOICE (taken aback) I will, Charles, thank you, that's... (very nice of you.) We always liked you, Charles. She hangs up. He presses OFF on the phone and opens his door - A VIOLENT FORCE BURSTS IN. A man, but a man possessed by most primitive homicidal fury - Wielding a HYPODERMIC NEEDLE - Plunging the needle in, again and again, like a knife Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  44 SAVAGE BLUR of images, different angles, hand-held CAMERA shocking effect. Charles fights back, waving his arms ineffectually, slapp the intruder. Useless. The attack is savage, relentless - Charles staggers back, falls. Like a wild beast, the attacker leaps: In for the kill. ANOTHER ANGLE. MOMENTS LATER. A foot. Laces being undone. The shoe being removed. Sock removed. Hands go to Charles’ belt. His shirt is already off. The intruder, Mouse face, slowly, pleasurably, strips Cha body... Note: Descriptions of Charles The Anorexic and Mouse Face are for reading purposes only. Their specific physical characteristics are immaterial. dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: "Aramaic?" ‘ HOBBES I know. Hobbes is playing over and over a short section in which gestures for the Priest to come in and get.killed, the Pr leaves, and Reese waves at the video camera...

dialogues.text: Edgar Reese drove a fuckin’ bus. He was smart, but self-educated, so a little Dutch? Maybe. But some ancient tongue only a few tribesmen speak??

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: So? He bats right and waves left. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  48 Hobbes turns up the sound and we hear:

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Reese did some of the sickest shit on record. He’s speaking a language 2000 years old. And you're worried ‘cause he’s ambidextrous???

dialogues.text: EXT. CHARLES’ APARTMENT. DAY. Icy crisp image of a nondescript building. COPS and CORON moving in and out, in slow motion. INT. CHARLES’ APARTMENT. DAY. The empty apartment, seen through the open hall door. A half-eaten grilled cheese sandwich on the counter. A syringe on the floor. A gaunt body face down in the bathtub. An unrinsed, toothpaste-laden toothbrush on the sink. Charles‘ clothes piled in the middle of the floor. The gaunt body being turned over onto its back. Written i magic marker on Charles’ chest are the numbers "5-6." Charles’ eyes are open. Wide. Hobbes looks at Charles, glances at Jonesy, then back at Charles. Does Hobbes recognize Charles...? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  In Hobbes’ hand: his two quarters going nervously... The kitchen table. A box of cornflakes, a container of mi a sugar bowl, and a half-eaten bowl of cereal. Carefully placed in a distinctive configuration. Mini-Stonehenge re

dialogues.text: {stares at them) It ain’t just the same objects. They're in the same place. Exact. {dourly) It’s like he’s laughin’ at us. Hobbes turns toward the wall where last time they found writing. This time there’s a mirror there. Hobbes is relieved. Casually he moves the mirror aside. There's writing underneath it. Slowly, forcing himself, Hobbes pushes the mirror farther until he can read: ARMAGEDDON.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Killer has a pretty high opinion of himself.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Not the first. Hobbes looks around the place...

dialogues.text: You know what’s scary?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: What ain’t?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Last night, going home, a guy walking the other way looked me in the eye. One of those looks like he knows you, you know? Jonesy nods.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: It was the guy in the bathtub, Jonesy. The stiff, it was him. Why would he look at me? Did he already know he was gonna die? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.text: Me neither. But I have to. (starting anywhere) It’s gonna be the same poison, right? Jonesy nods -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: How ‘bout the numbers on his chest? Seven was last Friday, now he’s back to five and six? Where’s six? Jonesy shrugs. The CORONERS go by, carrying Charles’ body wrapped in a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Who is this guy anyway?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Everything’s under Charles Olom, but it’s some kinda alias. We’re running his prints. Hobbes nods. Turns. Finds: His own image, staring back from the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: You can’t beat us, JH! You got too much flab, man! Sittin’ on your glutes all day. You need some gym work! Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.text: We can beat you, Loosh, but it‘1ll have to be next week. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES

dialogues.text: (soft, so Art can’t hear) But he's a spaz. (instantly, off Hobbes’ look) I'm sorry, I know, I - Hobbes sees Jonesy approaching, says firmly to Sam:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Cherish what you got, kid. Hobbes tosses the ball to Art and goes to Jonesy. Art war with Sam and Toby as Lucius puffs on his smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Hey, Lucius, how's pharmaceuticals? Lucius tokes on his cigarette as if it were a joint. Jone smiles, turns to Hobbes:

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Tiffany get you?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (There's more?) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: That's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: That’s not ik. Noons is the guy who killed the Roosky. It's his prints all over Muskavich’s apartment. Hobbes thinks.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Noons poisons Muskavich, dumps him in the tub, and sets out the cornflakes. Three days later somebody does the exact same thing to Noons. Exact.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Exact. ‘Cause Noons and Muskavich were actually killed by the same person.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Some kinda ringmaster? Hobbes nods -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I don't know, man, but I got a bad feeling.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Me too. (dourly} Like somebody's playin’ with my dick and it ain’t me. cut TO: EXT./INT. COUNTRY ROAD/HOBBES’ CAR. DAY. Hobbes drives through beautiful desolate landscape. Water everywhere. Lakes. Narrow roads between the lakes. It fee like the moon if the moon were mostly water. MUSIC accent this sense of being in spooky alien territory... The pavement stops. Fork in the road. Overgrown dirt road both directions. No signposts, no aids to the traveller. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  34 Hobbes consults Gretta’s FAX: both written instructions a diagrams...

dialogues.text: EXT. MILANO’S HOUSE. DAY. A dilapidated farmhouse set back from the road, surrounde three sides by water. Hobbes’ car turns down the long driveway, parks. As he walks toward the house, we realize: this is the hou from the opening of the movie... The WIND blows, creating a disquieting effect... Just before he reaches the house, Hobbes stops, looks aro There are bushes but no trees for several hundred yards. location has one distinctive feature: it would be impossi to approach by car or boat without being seen. INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. DAY. The windows are covered with decades of grime, so the roo dark. Hobbes flicks a switch but the electricity’s off. His eyes adjust to the light, or lack of it. A very creep place. Are there rats living here? Snakes? Monsters? Salvation-Army-style furniture, but nothing’s in the righ place. The desk is in the middle of the room. Chairs are turned over. There’s plaster on the floor, from a place w one wall was torn up. Every drawer is pulled out onto the floor, and old papers are scattered everywhere. INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. Hobbes looks in. Empty, barren, as if it had never been u Hobbes notices marks on the floor. He sweeps away the dir Gradually, to creepy effect, the painted outline of a spr body becomes discernible: this is where Milano died. INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. BEDROOM. Monastic: a simple cot, an old dresser. A dark sheet hang over one wall. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. BATHROOM. Empty, spartan. Movement. The ancient shower curtain is moving slightly. Something or someone is behind it. Hobbes hesitates... Steps forward... Yanks it back - An empty tub. On the wall over it is a broken window; the curtain was moving in the breeze. INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. Hobbes sits among the papers, slowly sifting through them He picks up one covered with some form of ancient writing A second piece of paper has similar writing. He turns a sheet of paper over: it’s a photograph. He holds it up to the light, sees: A_family. Father, mother, three-month-old child. A joyous now ironically joyous - image. ANOTHER ANGLE. Hobbes stands by a bookcase. Only one shelf is filled: wi old books. - Hobbes takes one down, leafs through it. Photographs of paintings and drawings: Demons, gargoyles, monsters. Hobbes leafs through a second book, a large one, with pho churches. He’s about to put the book back when he notices x 10 black-and-white photograph wedged into it. He takes out the photo, examines it: A CRUDE PAINTING. At the top are angels. Some seem to be pushing others out, expelling them from Heaven. The ones were expelled fall toward the bottom of the painting. The arms are outstretched, fingers pointing at, almost touchi the men and women walking along the bottom of the paintin The men and women’s faces are filled with horror and grie Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  56 Hobbes removes the photo, closes the book, looks around. He moves to the hall, glances for a last time, into the bathroom, into the bedroom... INT. BEDROOM. DAY. Casually, to check every possible contingency, he pulls d the sheet that's covering one wall of the bedroom: Under the sheet is the painting he just saw. Full sized, color, it’s powerful, creepy. . Hobbes stares at it. Blinks. Looks down at the photograph. He's comparing them, looking back and forth. He's noticed something. He goes to the window, holds the photo up to the light... looking at the lower right corner: In the photograph, that corner is white, perhaps unfinish But not in the painting. The painting is complete. INT. KITCHEN. In the back of the kitchen is a pantry. Most of the shelv hold old cans of food, etc. one shelf is filled with paint and brushes. From this she Hobbes grabs a can of turpentine. INT. BEDROOM. DAY. VARIOUS ANGLES. Hobbes is using the turpentine and an old rag to remove t surface paint from the lower right corner of the painting Gradually he uncovers the white wall underneath. But the wall is not entirely white. Underneath the surface layer of paint, over one section o white wall, something is written in small black letters. Hobbes applies more turpentine, rubs harder, harder...unt letters are visible. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.text: INT./EXT. HOBBES’ CAR/FREEWAY. NIGHT. Hobbes drives. Dark. Few surrounding cars. But when they come, their lights arc ominously across Hobbes’ face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes walking. Still thinking. The pattern of lights and solitary figure make a stark and beautiful image.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: When I want to think, I walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seedy neighborhood. Strip joints and hock shops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the night. The streets. Smells. The sense of strange possibilities...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes blinks. His face changes, snapping from reverie to alert. Footsteps. Scary MUSIC plays... He walks a few more steps. Confirms: Someone is following

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Sometimes you come face to face with your self. Hobbes glances over his shoulder - Sees no-one. Walks a few steps. Puzzled. Quickly stops and turns again, looks: Still no one in sight. The footsteps have stopped too. Hobbes resumes walking. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  58 The footsteps resume. There’s a powerful spooky sense that he’s being followed something invisible. He walks...slower...slower...coming to a decision. He can run. He can’t hide. He must face it. He stops, whirls -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runs back toward the footsteps - Sprinting down the street, looking every direction, every building, every doorway, every parked car. Nothing. Absolutely nothing. He stops, frustrated and winded. ...And spooked. JUMP BACK TO A STRANGE ANGLE. Someone is there... Someone is watching him...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. GRETTA’S APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY. A clear sunny day, the kind of day which makes the idea o seem almost absurd. Hobbes waits by the entrance. Gretta comes out, sees him, walks toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I went up there. She keeps walking. He walks with her.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What do the letters AAELZZ mean? She glances at him. Does she recognize the letters? We ca tell. And she still does not speak.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Your father wrote those letters on the wall and painted over them. They're alphabetical so maybe they're scrambled or -

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (reaching her car) Walk away. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  59

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (getting in car) If you enjoy your life, if there’s even one human being you care about er who depends on you: give this case to someone else.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I can’t do that. This is my job. She glances at him, starts her car.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: For your sake, I hope not. (beat) I'm late for class. She drives away.

dialogues.speaker: A SHEET OF PAPER.
dialogues.text: At the top are the letters AAELZZ, followed by the 720 permutations of these letters. Hobbes is going through th crossing out the ones that are clearly gibberish. We are: INT. UNIVERSITY LIBRARY. LATER. DAY. A musty library, leather chairs and big oak tables. Twent names remain on his list: Hobbes is checking them in a dictionary. He stops, having found something. Stares at i ZOOM IN ON THE dictionary and the definition: AZAZEL: In the Old Testament: an evil spirit. Hobbes stares at this. ANOTHER TIME CUT. Hobbes now has ancient books on the occult spread out ove table. He picks up one of the books. We see a list of Biblical names, including Azazel, followed by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tt is said they must have a host body to survive." Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  69 He thinks about this. Walks around the table picking up o book after another. As he looks at each, a piece of the t flashes up briefly in boldface: "They speak all the tongues of Babel." "Azazel goes by the left hand and has stolen the gift of song." "When they move as spirit, no man can resist." Hobbes stops, shakes his head. What am I doing? He notices an elderly CHINESE GENTLEMAN at the next table Hobbes stares at him, gets an idea. He reads again: "They speak all the tongues of Babel." Hobbes puts the book down. Hesitates. Walks over:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Can you teach me to say something in Chinese? cuT To: INT. PRECINCT. DAY. Schwab hands a FAX to Jonesy. Behind Jonesy’s desk are ph (living, dead) of Muskavich and Noons, their apartments, writing on the wall, etc. Hobbes is examining the crime-scene photos, wondering abo what he’s just read. Maguire comes up:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s cute -

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know it don’t mean diddly, but it sure makes ‘em nervous upstairs. Maguire walks away, and Hobbes turns to Jonesy. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You know: I'm startin’ to lose my sense of humor. (notices FAX) Whatchoo got?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes takes the FAX. Simultaneously we read and hear, fr the videotape:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (dry, irritated) Why’d you ask for me, I’m not a priest.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: No. (first in Aramaic, then cross- fading into the translation:) You're still pure. That’s why I couldn't enter you. (CONT. } INTERCUT: Hobbes’ face, his stunned reaction to this translation, with a more distant POV: someone watching...

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (V.0., CONT.)
dialogues.text: And even when I can, even when I’m spirit, I won’t. No. It’s better I get you for real. I'll fuck you up and down, left and right, coming and going. (CONT.) Hold on Hobbes‘ reaction to this, and then slowly, under v.0. that follows, the more distant POV MOVES, pulling ba out a small window into an alley, where: A CAT sits on the window sill, looking into the precinct. FOLLOW it as it jumps down from the window, jogs toward t front of the building... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  62

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (V.O., CONT.)
dialogues.text: I'll get so close to you...so close it breaks you. And if that doesn’t work? Well... (CONT . } The Cat reaches the entrance to the precinct and rubs aga CAB DRIVER who’s paused by the door to crush his cigarett

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (V.O., CONT.)
dialogues.text: I have other ways. I have so many many ways... The Cab Driver enters: INT. PRECINCT. OUTER ROOM. DAY. The Cab Driver walks to the front desk. As he goes, his h lightly brushes against a BLOND COP. The Blond Cop goes past the main desk, through the door i INT. PRECINCT. SQUAD ROOM. DAY. The Blond Cop heads for the Water cooler. He passes Tiffa touches her hair:

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW Schwab to Hobbes’ desk. Hobbes is still staring at FAX of the translation. He folds it up and mutters -
