He’s doing somet odd: surreptitiously unbuttoning one cuff, pulling it dow it covers his fingers. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  63

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: Hey, Hobbes, can you tell me something?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Shoot. Schwab leans across the desk - an oddly dominant posture trainee. He's supporting his body with his shirtcuffed ha

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: That Fax you got the other day. (off Hobbes’ look) The anonymous one, about Canada... For one long instant, Schwab seems physically threatening Hobbes... Is he about to leap over the desk and attack hi

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What about it? The moment for Schwab to attack...passes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: It was directions, right...? Now we see what Schwab is doing: While Hobbes looks at Sc face, Schwab is picking up Hobbes’ pen with his shirt cuf

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Directions to someplace up in the Lake District? Hobbes is wary. What’s this line of questioning about?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Schwab gets off the desk, stands back up.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful up there, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: Miles and miles of water... Hobbes nods. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  64 Out of Hobbes’ sight: Schwab folds a copy of the memo aro Hobbes’ pen.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I’m just curious. Why’d you go up there? Hobbes stares at him. Schwab smiles. He’s backing up. Hobbes suspects.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Why do you ask, Schwab? Schwab's smile becomes overt, mocking...and to our astoni he starts to sing. Under his breath, just for Hobbes:

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: "Time...is on my side... Yes it is..." Freaky. Same song Reese sang at his execution. Hobbes is stunned - Schwab backs into Lou, their hands touching. Out of Hobbe vision: Lou takes the folded memo (with the pen) from Sch hand. And the song moves too:

dialogues.speaker: SCHWAB
dialogues.text: "Time..."

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: " \..is on my side, Yes it is." Hobbes knows he’s watching something weird. Lou's walking away, bumps into a YOUNG BLACK COP named MI Hobbes sees the change in both of them after they touch. And the song passes again:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: "I’11 come runnin’ back... I’ll come runnin’ back..." Hobbes stands as Mike heads out toward the front desk -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey Mike - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  65 Too late. Mike goes through the door - Hobbes moves quickly after him - INT. PRECINCT. OUTER ROOM. DAY. Hobbes rushes out, looks toward the exit door: no Mike - Turns, sees: Mike is behind the main desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Mike? Mike turns:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s the skin, Hobbesy? Nothing strange there. Hobbes looks toward the door - Two people going out: a SOCIETY WOMAN 52, and a short man ALMOST A MIDGET. The Almost-Midget turns back, looks at Hobbes, and grins. Hobbes sprints after him - EXT. PRECINCT. DAY. Crowded street. Hobbes rushes out, looks one way, then th other; can’t see, can't see; finally spots the Almost-Mid

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey you! The Almost-Midget doesn’t seem to hear. Is he hurrying aw Hobbes shakes his head frustrated, doesn’t know what to d An idea comes - He stares after the Almost-Midget - Shouts: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wwa_je-dow Nee Shu-shay! Wwa je-dow Nee  Shu-shay! SUBTITLES read: "I know who you are. I know who you are!" The Almost Midget does not react, but, nearby: The Society Woman turns her head - Hobbes sees it - Their eyes meet - Frozen moment... It’s her. And he knows it. The Society Woman _is Azazel.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (stunned; mutters) Holy shit... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mandarin. Very clever.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Thank you. He approaches her. She smiles. Makes no movement to flee. And we see: she's holding the memo which covers Hobbes’ pen.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I do know who you are. She just looks at him. Defiantly. Doesn’t believe it._

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Azazel. Her face shifts, fast like slides: surprise/disbelief/fur Her eyes small and red. Her voice savage and husky:

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where‘d you get that, from Milano‘s place? There are some things, Pal, you shouldn't know. And if you know, you should never ever tell. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www She touches the FAT MAN next to her, who mutters to Hobb

dialogues.speaker: FAT MAN
dialogues.text: Beware my wrath. Hobbes blinks. The Fat Man turns away, touches someone. Then quickly tou someone else. We gather: the first person did not work. We watch the demon move. And we see, though Hobbes does n that with each touch, the sheet of paper with the pen als passes. One person bumps into another, another. In a matt of seconds, the demon could be any one of a hundred peopl Hobbes stands there pondering what the Society Woman just realizing: He made a mistake. INT. PRECINCT. DETECTIVES ROOM. MOMENTS LATER. Hobbes on the phone, listening to a line ring. As he wait he’s searching his desk top -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: {to the room) Hey, has anybody seen my pen? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's Hobbes. I saw it. It came here. JI spoke its name aloud. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Before I make another stupid mistake, will you please have lunch with me? (off her silence) I need to know something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subtly, eerily: this is more than an establishing shot. T is a warning. The restaurant is being watched. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  a o INT. MIDDLE-EASTERN RESTAURANT. DAY. Hobbes sits at a booth. The table is covered with appetiz He's looking out the window. It‘s lunch hour, and the sid outside is filled with people casually brushing against e other. Any one of them could be the demon...

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi. He looks up, sees her.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. She nods. Sits. Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You don’t want to talk? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You're scared? She looks warily around the restaurant - and nods again.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: But not too scared to keep doing whatever you’re doing. You just want to keep a low profile.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (smiles, nods) Thank you. (for seeing who I am)

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What else? You’d like to help me, but you can’t. Her voice comes so quietly we almost don’t hear it:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: We're not supposed to know. We're not supposed to see. Like the mafia: they don’t even exist. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  69 Hobbes stares at her...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Can they be killed?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (stares at him, forcefully:) Don‘t try it, okay? He nods thoughtfully, not necessarily in response to her question. He's looking her over...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You say you're scared, but I don’t feel it, I don’t sense it -

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I‘m also prepared. (casually) We all face death every day.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Tellin’ me. (hesitates) Can I ask you something personal?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Everything is personal if you’re a person. He laughs -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Being..."prepared"...is that why you live alone?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: There’s a difference. (off his look) Between risking for yourself and for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Go on. She shoots him a look. He was right: These are the questi that cross the line, and she must decide now whether to c that line with him... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  70

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: If I had someone, I'd want to share: my life, thoughts, my work. But if I shared this, I‘d put them at risk. I don’t have a right to do that.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You can talk to me. (off her look) I don’t mean you have to. I don’t mean there’s anything else tied to it. Just: you can if you want to. She hesitates, reaches across, almost touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Thanks, maybe I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch them from a distance. Though they themselves don know it, they look like a couple. They’re walking, not qu hand-in-hand, but there’s a naturalness between them, an ease... CLOSER ANGLE. Now we hear what Gretta’s saying:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I keep thinking...hoping...well, after what happened to my Dad, maybe I'll have luck the other way. Maybe one day, if I’m good and I surround myself with their images: maybe I’1ll see an angel.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (gentle, still skeptical) That would be something.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I always wonder...if they really have wings. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  ANOTHER ANGLE. SLIGHTLY WIDER. MOVING. Now their voices are just murmurs. We’re moving with them watching them through a speckled mass of bushes, branches This is the POV of the demon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the street: Gretta nods, smiles, thanks Hobbes for a nice time. He go inside. We hear: someone whistling. And what he’s whistli sends a chill up us, for it is the same EERIE TUNE that h been playing each time the demon is around... Gretta moves down the street. The DEMON’S POV moves after her. He continues whistling. MUSIC underscores the tune... Gretta’s strolling happily, looking in windows, enjoying outside of time. DEMON’S POV moves diagonally across the street, to her si Moving quickly now, closing ground. She stops to look in a store window... The CAMERA gains more ground, then has to stop, because G can see the Demon, peripheral vision. The whistling cease THE CAMERA turns, looks into another shop window (lingeri HOLD a beat, then PAN AGAIN: Gretta’s back on the move. The CAMERA follows, slowly at first, then closing quickly ominously - Now only a few feet away - A FINAL SURGE. A rush, an attack - We pass a store window with signs: SALE! A glint of steel as the Demon rushes forward - We wince, want to cry out a warning - A KNIFE flashes forward -

dialogues.speaker: AT THE INSTANT OF IMPACT
dialogues.text: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  Gretta turns into the store -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s going into a revolving door - The knife gets caught in the door. It’s pinned, then wren sideways and thrown to the ground. Gretta is now in one revolving section, the knife in the section. The CAMERA hesitates, looks through the door: a half-doze shoppers inside, milling around. The CAMERA pushes forward, into the revolving door... The demon is entering the store. But as the demon enters, the CAMERA stays outside, pans d the revolving door comes back around...and delivers the b knife back out onto the sidewalk. INT. STORE. DAY. The CAMERA enters as the demon, then swings laterally and back, so it’s NO LONGER THE DEMON‘S POV... We see everyone in the store, including Gretta. Because o way the shoppers are milling around, we can‘t tell which the demon is occupying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of people move close to Gretta as she stands at counter. One bumps idly against her, then another. Is thi the demon’s_ touch??? Behind them: A PUDGY OLD WOMAN WITH THICK GLASSES (think Hitchcock) en the store holding the butgher knife. uo

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: (concerned) This was on the sidewalk outside. Did anyone...does anyone... Gretta sees the knife, realizes she may be in danger - She glances around at. the other shoppers - They all look perfectly innocent. Gretta eases toward the door. As Gretta goes by, The Old Woman (now holding the butcher by the handle, as an assailant would) gives her a sweet s Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  73 A THIN WOMAN makes a sudden movement, putting herself in Gretta’s path, a collision is inevitable - Like a halfback avoiding a tackler, Gretta arches her bod slips past the Thin Woman - The Thin Woman grabs the man (MOUSTACHE) in front of her He lunges after Gretta - She’s rushing to the revolving door - He's right behind her, reaching for her - She pushes the revolving door - Mustache is about to touch her - The revolving door moves - But his hand is in her section -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stops the door. His HAND, inches from her, wiggling like a squashed bug - His FACE, smiling at her -

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTACHE
dialogues.text: Who are you? She shoves the revolving door. It won’t budge. His hand strains toward her...

dialogues.speaker: MOUSTACHE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Just tell me who you are. She pushes again, with every ounce of her strength... The door starts to move. His hand is still in her compartment . She glances back as she pushes, sees: His face pressed against the glass, contorted in laughter pain - She pushes harder, frantic - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  EXT. STORE. DAY. She exits the revolving door, into heavy pedestrian traff Mustache emerges after her, throwing people rudely aside She's shorter, thinner, weaves like a halfback - A cab. Someone getting out, about to close the door - She jumps in - Moustache leaps after her - She slams the door - INT. CAB. DAY. His hand lands - SMACK! - on her window. She jams down on the lock - His fingers are spread over the glass, his face grinning

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Drive! The CABBIE peels out. She looks back through the rear win Moustache is smiling and waving after her like he’s her f The hand he’s waving is the one that was caught in the do It is broken and flopping slightly. CUT To: INT. PRECINCT. SQUAD ROOM. DAY. Hobbes sits at his desk staring at Reese‘s photo. A shadow falls over him. Spooky. He looks up quickly, sees: Tiffany. She gestures with her head: that way. INT. PRECINCT. MAGUIRE'S OFFICE. DAY. Maguire sits behind his desk. Somehow it feels larger, mo judicial. Hobbes sticks his head in the door. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, come in. Hobbes enters, sits. Fiddles with his quarters.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: So. How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: That‘s good. These murders got you wound up?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Bag the chocolates, Maguire. What’s goin’ on?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Where were you when Muskavich and Noons got killed?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Where was I? (amused) What, I'm a suspect?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Not to me you’re not, but...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What’s this, the phone records? I’d do that, wouldn't I?, if I was the killer, I’d call home to talk to myself and plant evidence against me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: (shrugs, doesn’t like this) Maybe you'd phone your brother or -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Oh, right. "Art, I just killed someone, and I’m hungry. Fix me a burger, huh?" Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www 75  76

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: There’s something else, Hobbes. Prints.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: .-My prints? Maguire stares.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: On what? Maguire looks at Hobbes’s hands. Hobbes looks down himself, opens his palm: two quarters.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Quarters? You found quarters with ...(my prints?) But... Somebody could've picked my pocket, or...or when I bought something...

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you know how we always said this could be a cop? Hobbes nods warily.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Well, it’s startin’ to look embarrassing. Do us both a favor, huh? Save your ass and solve this thing. EXT. PRECINCT. DAY. Hobbes walks thoughtfully to his car. As he puts the key in, he notices a piece of paper folded his windshield wiper. Some kind of flyer? He takes it, opens it. Z00M IN on the print as we hear, softly:

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY LADY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They didn’t crucify him because he was bad. I just had to convince a few people he was bad. Hobbes whirls around to see if anybody's watching him. No Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks back at the paper. Stares. Crumples it. Freaked out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes gets out of his car, heads for the pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes on the phone as a voice answers -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey Loosh, I’m outside. You got time for a consultation? INT. DRUG STORE. REAR PHARMACY AREA. DAY. Hobbes sits in back with Lucius, who we met on the basket court. Lucius wears a white pharmacist’s coat and is fill two prescriptions, one with each hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: gH, my man. Welcome to the candy store. His eyes do a fast scan of the area. Like a juggler, he t one of the pills toward his face. Like a lizard, he stick his tongue and snags it. Gulp. So smooth and fast: did it really happen?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: Prozac: so good. So what’s what? (before Hobbes can reply) I know, nobody left downtown knows jack about jack so you gotta quiz Lucius, right? What’s the bag?, rare toxins? Some new synth narcotic?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I’m not here on drugs, Loosh. You were alone once. Chasing someone twice as good as you, twice as smart, no clues. You went out - too far - but you got him. Lucius’ act has imploded. This is the last thing he wants talk about. He mutters: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  78

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: Mosher.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: How? How'd you find him?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: (to end conversation:) Luck.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: It wasn’t luck. (It broke you.) Good luck doesn’t break somebody. LucIUS (almost nasty) Close your eyes, JH. Smell. Hear. Feel. You sense him near, hit out. But always to the side. Oblique.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: A great criminal’s like a genius, man. You can’t beat Einstein at relativity. If he’s got genius, you gotta admire it, go with it, use it. Hobbes considers this.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Greatness destroys, know what I'm talkin’? Lucius juggles four pills and catches them: two in “each canister. cur TO: EXT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT BUILDING. EVENING. Hobbes walks from his car toward the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Une. Surprised, Hobbes looks around, sees Sam up in a tree wit Toby. Sam smiles at Hobbes and waves. Hobbes waves back, slows for a second as though disturbed thought he cannot quite articulate...and goes on. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  79 INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. EVENING. Hobbes comes in, hears the shower running, goes into his Everything about his attitude says: the day is over, now home and I can relax. And of course this attitude tells u things just appear ordinary. Something is about to happen INT. HOBBES’ BEDROOM. EVENING. Hobbes takes off his jacket, starts to unbutton his shirt He stops. Looks around the room. Something’s bothering hi he doesn’t know what it is. Slowly his eyes scan the room And come to rest on his desk. INT. HOBBES‘ APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. EVENING. Hobbes comes out of his room, sees Art moving down the ha his bathrobe. He has a towel around his head and is dryin hair, his face...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey Art, you didn’t move my address book, did you?

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Have you seen my address book? Art shakes his head, nervously, tries to move past Hobbes Something's strange. Art is holding his towel over his. r eye. He’s not drying his face, he’s covering his eye. Hobbes stops Art, gently pulls the towel down, revealing: Art has a black eye. He blinks, musters the best face he can...

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: I fell.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: what? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  80

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: I fell or something.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Art... People don’t fall down and hurt their eye.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: They don’t? Hobbes shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Ooh. (his face works, nervously) Well...something...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: It's okay, say it.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: It's...Sammy. He hit me. On Hobbes‘ face. Blinking, realizing... EXT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT BUILDING. EVENING. (FLASHBACK) Reprise the moment we just saw, Hobbes coming home. Only there’s different music and we notice different things:

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Unc. Sam's tone of voice is slightly mocking. Hobbes, looks, sees Sam. Sam is smiling down from the tree. But now his smile has slightly superior, slightly sinister quality. He waves - with his left hand. And in his right hand he’s holding: Hobbes' address book. BACK TO SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: He didn’t mean to, Johnny. Really. It was an accident. But Hobbes is already sprinting toward the apartment door Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  81 INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT BUILDING. HALL. EVENING. Hobbes tears into the hall - Bumps right into Sam - Grabs him, yanks him up hard to look him in the eye - Bewilderment and fear on Sam’s face; Hobbes is a little r out of control -

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Uncle John? Hobbes sees that Sam is now clear of the demon

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Where's Toby?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ahh. Still outside, I guess. Hobbes drops Sam and sprints away, down the hall EXT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT BUILDING. EVENING. Hobbes runs out of the building, sees: Toby sitting on the hood of a car reading Hobbes’ address

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Leave them alone! Toby smiles, which of course makes Hobbes even more enrag

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Leave my family alone!

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Why? You come after me, I come after you and yours. Enraged, Hobbes runs toward him - Toby runs too - with the speed of youth. Hobbes sprinting as fast as he can - Toby’s going even faster. He swerves into the street, wea recklessly through traffic - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  82 Hobbes watches, alarmed - Cars honk and hit their brakes - but Toby is smooth, fear He makes it across. A SCRAWNY MAN has stopped to watch Toby’s dare-deviling. runs near him, lunges, grabs his arm. The Scrawny man moves away, and Toby stops to catch his b Hobbes passes him. Like a concerned parent:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Go home, Toby. Up ahead, the Scrawny Man reaches in the open window of a American car, unlocking the door. He gets in - Hobbes walks toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facing the American car. In the right side of the frame: Hobbes is walking toward the car. ° Left side of frame: the Scrawny Man opens the glove compartment, sets something on the dash. He rips open his shirt and hunches over; he’s doing something we can’t see Hobbes getting nearer, nearer - The Scrawny Man working on his chest. Something glints on dashboard. What he placed there: a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOCK. The Scrawny Man leaps out, fires at Hobbes Hobbes jumps to one side - Scrawny Man keeps shooting Hobbes falls, rolls behind a parked car, draws his gun Silence. Hobbes gets up, crouches. He’s unharmed. He peeks out, instantly pulls back... Then looks out again: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  83 The Scrawny Man is standing in the middle of the street. His pistol is pointed at the ground. His face is curiously blank.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAWNY MAN
dialogues.text: What's a matter, pal, (you) afraid to fight me? Hobbes thinks. Composes himself. Steps out from behind the car. Face to face. Gunfight on Elm Street. The Scrawny Man's face curls into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAWNY MAN
dialogues.text: I knew you’d come out. I know you, Hobbes. I know who you are. {contemptuously) Wwa_je-dow Nee Shu-shay! Hobbes reacts to the Mandarin - The Scrawny Man starts to slowly raise his gun. Very slow A long suspended moment. Should Hobbes kill the demon or. The Scrawny Man's gun is rising slowly, inevitably... Then his arm jerks up, aiming - Hobbes whips his own gun up, fires - The Scrawny Man spins, falls. Lies motionless. Hobbes comes tentatively toward the body... Looks down at it. A collapsed hunk of flesh. Hobbes squats, feels the neck: no pulse. He sighs with relief and almost a smile, believing he has killed the demon. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  84

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD CAMERA
dialogues.text: On the Scrawny Man...then rising...floating up...moving t sidewalk. ALL SOUND CEASES. We've seen this camera move before, at Reese's execution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘The CAMERA COMES TO REST ABOVE a TEENAGE GIRL, 16, who's watching the scene. The CAMERA SWOOPS DOWN ONTO HER FACE: She LAUGHS MALICIOUSLY -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes spins, looks at the Teenage Girl. A realization co to him. No, it can’t be. But it is:

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: Wake up, Hobbes. My spirit’s not that easy to kill. She skips happily away. Hobbes stares after her in horror...rage...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey! She keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (very strong) Hey you!!! She turns casually, almost amused -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just kill me?! - She looks surprised he can even ask. Isn‘t it obvious?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL
dialogues.text: (feigning injury) But...I‘m still having fun. (subdued, vicious) Aren‘t you still having fun? She turns and goes. Hobbes stares after her... cuT TO: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  8s SAME LOCATION. MINUTES LATER. Cops swarm. Jonesy is interviewing a DIGNIFIED BLACK MAN saying the Scrawny Man fired first. Maguire talks to Hobb

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: We got a weird situation here. Seems like you're kinda specializing in weird situations, and that in itself is getting a little weird, huh? (looks at corpse) The guy was a schoolteacher. We know he fired first, witnesses corroborate, but his gun was filled with blanks. Plus: he got the gun outta someone else’s car.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. (realizing) It was all a set up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) He set it up for you to kill him?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now it’s letters. They turn, see: On the schoolteacher’s chest, in magic marker: The letter They stare at it, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: "Easy." He’s sending me some kind of message.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: The killer’s sending you a message? Hobbes? This time you are the killer.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Sort of. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  86

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: No fucking "sort of!" No breaks! No benefit of the doubt! We're goin’ back to the precinet, huh? Off Hobbes -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MAGUIRE’S OFFICE. NIGHT. Hobbes sits facing Maguire and Lou.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: That's all you can say? You were chasing this teacher ‘cause he stole your address book? Hobbes nods.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) As you know, you have to turn in your gun till we get a formal inquiry. Hobbes stares at Maguire. Someone knocks at the door. Lou goes. Hobbes takes out his gun with two fingers (mimicking a su carefully giving up a weapon) and drops it on Maguire's d Lou is whispering with someone at the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (to Maguire) You want my badge too? - Maguire shakes his head. Lou moves away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I don’t exactly like this, Hobbes. Lou whispers to Maguire. Maguire thinks. As Lou leaves the room:

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I understand you lost your pen, huh? you were lookin’ around yesterday for your pen? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  87 Hobbes thinks for a split-second -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You found it? {off Maguire’s silence) Where?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: In that schoolteacher’s pocket. Hobbes nods. Stands.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Unless you're gonna charge me with planting evidence against myself, I’m gonna go.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Go. INT. PRECINCT. NIGHT. Hobbes exits Maguire’s office. The precinct is empty except for Jonesy, working at his d Hobbes stares at Jonesy. A Quintessential Cop: 55, overwe corrupt yet incorruptible. Puffing away on his cigarette. Hobbes walks over, sits on his desk. Thinks. Watches: Maguire exits his office, turns out the light, and goes. Hobbes walks to the coffee machine, pours two cups. He returns, dropping one cup off on Jonesy’s desk. Jonesy nods thanks, keeps working. Hobbes sits again on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: {w/o looking up) Hey. Beat. Hobbes waves Jonesy’s smoke away from his face. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  88

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Jonesy? What‘s the point of life?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: The point?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Of life?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry ‘bout that teacher. It was a clean shoot.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: It’s not that. I’m really asking. Jonesy nods. Considers it.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: The point is: we catch bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Not good enough. Jonesy shrugs, goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Okay, shoot me for talking like this.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Hey, it‘s two in the morning, you can talk any weird shit you want.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Good. ‘Cause... What're we doing here, man? Why do we exist?, why does anything exist? Us, birds, trees, water -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Could be God, Hobbes. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  89

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah, could be, but I have a hard time believing we’re part of some huge moral experiment conducted by a being greater than we are. A being greater than we are shouldn’t give a shit about us. Five billion human beings?? We’re like ants, man! Do we care what ants do, from a moral standpoint?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (an easy one) Ants? No.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: But if there’s no God, how’d we get here? See what I’m saying? Go back to the beginning, the very beginning of time, the big bang or whatever you wanna call it.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m with you, the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Right. Now what came before?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (irritated) Nothing. It’s the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: No no, sorry. Something as big as the universe doesn’t just appear out of nowhere; somebody or some thing had to start it. It’s like: even if there is a God...who made God? Jonesy stares at Hobbes, puffs on his cigarette...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: I’m followin’ you, Hobbes...but I'm losin’ you at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I know, I know -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Are we headed somewheres here, or... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  90

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m asking you. If there’s a purpose to life, we better figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Maybe you figure it, you die. (snaps fingers) Heart attack, stroke. Like: if you know what's what, you aren’t allowed to stick around anymore; you get promoted. Hobbes nods. What Jonesy’s saying makes an odd kind of se

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile: Dolores says we're here to do one thing.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: One thing? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Different. It’s different for everybody. Hers is lasagna.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: One thing, not two?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Maybe two, I don’t know. It’s just her opinion, Hobbes. It’s like: a moment comes, you either do the right thing or the wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: How do you know when the moment comes? Hobbes’ phone rings. They both look at it. It rings again. The same thought has come to both of them

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Like: this could be it for me? (My moment?) Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  91

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: There’s the beauty (of it), Hobbes: you never know. Hobbes looks at the phone, looks at Jonesy... Picks it up:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: John Hobbes. Silence. Hobbes shakes his head, mutters into the receive

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey look, I’m not in the mood - GRETTA’S VOICE I can’t believe you‘re there. It’s Gretta. I just... I wanted to see if you’re okay. I talked to your brother -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I killed somebody, Gretta. (softly, so Jonesy can’t hear) I was trying to kill the demon, and I shot a teacher. GRETTA’S VOICE I'm sorry, John. I'm truly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Well: you warned me. GRETTA’S VOICE I tried to, but -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Azazel can move after his host body dies? . GRETTA’S VOICE Yes. A short distance, a short time.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: But he can be killed? GRETTA’S VOICE He must be. ...And I’m afraid you and I are supposed to do it. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  92 He shakes his head. This is too much.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Gretta...I’m just a cop, okay? I'm only a cop. He hangs up, looks at Jonesy...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I'm going home to sleep, and I’m gonna sleep all weekend, and nothin’ better wake me.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOBBES’ BEDROOM. NIGHT. Dark, quiet, peaceful... Hobbes’ gasping face hurties up into frame. Nightmare. He looks around. Blinking, nervous. Everything’s fine. Windows closed, moon shining outside; reads 4:30. He heaves a sigh and curls up, tries to sleep

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOBBES’ BEDROOM. MORNING. He wakes to sunshine, the sound of birds; his curtains bi gently in the morning breeze... He stretches, sighs. He’s feeling better. INT. HOBBES‘ BATHROOM. MORNING. He washes his face. He brushes his teeth. He turns on the shower. He pulls off his t-shirt and feels the water temperature: fine. He turns back toward the mirror, starts to bend down to r his boxer shorts - Stops. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  93 Face goes white. Slowly he stands again. Turns to face the mirror: On his chest is written the letter E. Massive adrenalin hit. Re hurtles out of the bathroom, sees: The open window, curtains moving. It was closed last nigh Hobbes goes to his dresser, takes a pistol from the top d INT. HOBBES‘ APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. MORNING. Hobbes‘ door eases open, he emerges. Looks, sees: Everything seems normal. Sam sits on the floor in his paj He's watching Saturday morning cartoons and playing with bunch of toy cars - Hobbes hides the pistol: from Sam’s view.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sure. Hobbes heaves a small sigh of relief. Sam is making car engine noises. Hobbes looks around for Art or for other signs of disturb Sees nothing unusual.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey. (with a smile) What were you doing last night? Hobbes stops. The question sends him into a weird psychological torque...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (flat) How do you mean? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  94

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You were doin’ something funny, you were tickling me. (as Hobbes stares, paralyzed) Tickling my chest. Like someone forced to confront a horrible fate, Hobbes w slowly over to Sam. Hesitates. Unbuttons the boy’s pajama top. Printed on Sam’s chest in magic marker are the letters: K

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: {still playful, amused) Why'd you write that?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (strangled voice) I guess...I was trying to remind myself: there’s something I gotta do. (suddenly realizes:) Where’s your Dad?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: In the bedroom. He’s a sleepy head. Hobbes whips his head around, looks at the clock: 9:30. At this sight, Hobbes knows. INT. ART & SAM‘S ROOM. MORNING. Shades drawn; just a little light spills in. Silhouette. Art lies on his side, turned away from the do away from Hobbes. Hobbes enters frame, comes around the bed, kneels. He can Art's face and we can’t. He touches Art‘s neck, feeling for a pulse... The angle of Hobbes’ head drops slightly. He gently pulls down the covers. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  95 He slowly opens Art’s pajamas and looks at his chest. SMASH IN TO CLOSE ON ART’S CHEST, the letters: EL. ANOTHER ANGLE. Hobbes pulls the covers back up, as he found them. He kisses Art’s head...stands...walks out of the shot. From this distance and angle it still looks like Art is sleeping peacefully. INT. HOBBES’ APARTMENT. DAY. Hobbes closes the door gently behind him. He's carrying s of Sam‘s clothes. As he crosses the room, somehow he pulls himself together Says gently, without hint of his internal disturbance:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: We gotta get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOBBES’ BUILDING. HALL. DAY. Hobbes is carrying a small duffle for Sam. As they walk:

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Where’re we goin’?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: .-.I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (pleased) It‘s a surprise? (slowly) Why aren’t we taking my Dad? (tentatively) Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: He needs some extra sleep. Beat. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  96 EXT. HOBBES’ STREET. DAY. Two COPS in a green car watch Hobbes drive out of the bas garage. One of them picks up his radio mike:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST COP
dialogues.text: He's leaving. Should we pick him up?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: I don’t have the warrant yet. Just tail him. The First Cop hangs up the mike as the other Cop pulls ou follows Hobbes’ car, which is going slowly down the stree Suddenly Hobbes makes a right turn, speeds down an inclin a basement parking garage -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes comes out the other side of the parking garage int narrow alley and rams the accelerator. THE CAMERA STARTS TO RISE...higher...higher...as Hobbes c crosses the neighborhood, going through alleys and drivew and parking garages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes pulls into a yellow zone next to a subway stop. Ho jumps out, Sam scrambles across the seat, gets out Hobbes side. ~ THE CAMERA STARTS TO PAN as Hobbes and Sam go down the su stairs, KEEPS PANNING to a store window filled with Tvs.. ON TV: The Schoolteacher's body lying in the street. WITN talking. A photo of HOBBES. The news "headline" reads: "N Witnesses Say Cop Murdered Teacher." INT. SUBWAY CAR. DAY. Hobbes sits with Sam, feeling relieved. Gives the boy a h A SMALL POLISH WOMAN across the way is staring at Hobbes. When he notices, she glances quickly away - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  97 The subway rolls on, a moment passes... Hobbes sees: Over the Polish Woman’s head is a religious advertisement: a Biblical quotation citing Chapter and ve He stares at this. Blinks. Fumbles in his pocket for pen and paper. Writes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then he adds: Ezekiel 7, 5-6 He’s stunned. The Polish Woman whispers to the MIDDLE-AGED NURSE sittin to her. The Nurse glances at Hobbes, shrugs... Hobbes sees this. Looks down the row of people across the Most are reading the paper or staring off blankly. But te yards down A SHORT MAN is also staring. Something is up.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (whispers to Sam) Don‘t stand up, but we’re getting off at the next stop. Sam nods, pleased; to him this feels like a game. The train rolls into the station. Hobbes holds Sam’s hand, keeping him seated as OTHER PASS stand up and approach the doors. A COLLEGE COUPLE sits across the way. The Girl is now gla subtly at Hobbes... The subway doors open, people get out... Hobbes waits. Other people get in... Finally: Hobbes squeezes Sam's hand - Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  98 They get up quickly and slip through the closing doors - INT. SUBWAY STATION. PLATFORM. DAY. Hobbes and Sam come out, turn to the right - A COP is twenty feet away. He looks at Hobbes - Hobbes turns Sam gracefully the other direction and they

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Fast but not too fast. Sam nods. Hobbes hears footsteps approach from behind. Hi mind races as he tries to figure out what to do...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (unsure of the i.d.) Excuse me? Sir? Hobbes whirls, punches - Connects to the chin - The Cop falls -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Run! Hobbes and Sam sprint down the platform, out the exit doo OTHER PASSENGERS watch in astonishment. EXT. SUBWAY STATION. DAY. Hobbes and Sam run up the stairs. When they reach the top they turn right and start to walk. At the corner is a bus. Hobbes glances casually back towa the subway: no one’s coming. They board the bus. cur TO: EXT. PUBLIC PARK. DAY. A big park, in a lousy neighborhood. Clumps of trees and bushes. -Hobbes and Sam are hiding in a dense thicket. Ho keeps a close look-out: watching the park, the street, th vacant lot across the street... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  99

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Okay, this is what it is. You saw the police are after me. They think I did something bad.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I'm really not sure. Whatever it is, I didn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (nods thoughtfully) I saw that once, on a show.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. There's nothing more to say. Sam has completely accepted word. He ruffles the boy’s hair:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You want something to eat? MINUTES LATER. Sam stands on the sidewalk near the vacant lot, buying tw dogs and a coke from a STREET VENDER. Hobbes is in the bushes, keeping an eye on the boy. But slowly his focus changes. He’s looking past Sam, at the vacant lot: THREE HOMELESS cooking something over a large fire. Surrounding the fire an area 10 yards wide where grass is burned from similar Hobbes stares at it, mutters:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Scorched earth. His mind is racing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes is in a phone booth. He keeps a vigilant eye on everyone in the vicinity. Sam crouches nearby, standing g Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  100

dialogues.speaker: . HOBBES
dialogues.text: Lucius? Hobbes. LUCIUS’ VOICE Jesus, man. You’re ail over the news -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: So I gather. {looking around) I can’t talk long. Lemme tell you want I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving shadows. Hobbes and Sam slip from the roof of one building onto the roof of another. Hobbes looks around nervously. Starts down the fire escape. EXT. FIRE ESCAPE. NIGHT. Hobbes and Sam come down onto a landing, look in, see Gre her pajamas. Hobbes knocks on the window. She whirls, frightened. Sees him. Is relieved, and yet... She approaches the window with a touch of trepidation. He sees it. She reaches the window. She’s still uncertain whether to the security lock and open it the rest of the way. Hobbes sticks his hand through the open window. The gestu is - curiously, horribly - reminiscent of the man with th Moustache reaching for her. But of course it means something completely different. To me. Trust me. Trust I’m not bearing the demon. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  101 She smiles almost wistfully. Looks at his face... Raises her hand... Their palms meet. Joined. Hold. Their eyes are joined too. She undoes the security catch, As Hobbes helps the boy inside:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Gretta, this is Sam. She smiles, instantly at the kid’s level:

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Hi Sam. Sam grins at her. She glances at:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Can I see your Bible? MINUTES LATER. Hobbes leafs through the Bible...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Ezekiel... {finding it) Chapter 7, verses 5 and... "And mine eye shali not spare thee, neither will I have pity: but I will recompense thy ways upon thee, and thine abominations shall be in the midst of thee: and ye shall know that I am the LORD. Thus saith the LORD GOD: An evil, an only evil, behold, it is come." He lowers the book, somewhat stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Azazel. An age of darkness. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  102

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (nods) It‘s coming.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: No. It's already begun. Hobbes nods again. Stares at Sam, who‘s having a snack, a blinks. Comes back to reality, back to what he must do:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Azazel wrote on Sam's chest. Unless I do something, he’s next. MINUTES LATER. Sam sits on the floor. Sweet classical music plays. Grett taking down small glass figurines, angels for him to play

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Now these are the great angels: Michael, and Raphael, and Metatron. And this is Chochma, he’s very wise...Sandalphon: very tall, don’t you think?...and of course Shekinah: she’s a personal favorite of mine ‘cause she’s a girl. Sam laughs -

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: (playfully) Which one do you like best? He smiles. His eyes are dancing. ANOTHER ANGLE. MOMENTS LATER. Sam is now playing with the angels, making them fly and k each other, acting out some child’s fantasy... Gretta and Hobbes watch from across the room. This is the first real chance to talk:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Tell me what's in the news. She reacts. Hadn’t wanted to say anything, but since he a Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  103

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: They found your brother this afternoon. He nods, pained.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: And that teacher? Yesterday? Two new witnesses say you shot first and you planted his gun.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m public enemy number one.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Just like my Dad. Meaning she knows he’s being framed. He smiles gratefully At least she still has faith in him.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: So it’s okay?, we can stay here? She nods. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: _ HOBBES
dialogues.text: He’1l take the couch, I’1l take the rug. She looks at him...considers it... Shakes her head. INT. HER BEDROOM. NIGHT. She lies in the bed, watching him. He's taking off his clothes, down to t-shirt and boxer sh Gets in next to her. Beat. She decides something. Under the covers, she takes off her pajamas, drops them b bed.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What’re you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I want to hold you. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  104 Beat. He takes off his t-shirt and boxers, drops them.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: That's better. They embrace. The CAMERA RISES slowly to the wall, the image of an ANGE The Angel's mouth is open as though crying out in ecstasy

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Near as I can figure, we're vessels. (CONT. } ANOTHER ANGLE. LATER. CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES to discover them: in bed, cuddled tog

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA, (CONT., 0.S.)
dialogues.text: When we sing, we're vessels that hold song. When we're like this, we hold Ged, {finally ON CAMERA) and when we die: our souls depart and we aren't vessels anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: And when Azazel enters us? She shakes her head; won’t say it. He does:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: We hold evil. I’m scared, Gretta. I'm scared the demon will enter me.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: I don't think it can. Some people are -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Not by touch. As spirit. When its host body dies, it can move as spirit, right?, isn’t that what you said? A short distance, a short time? (quoting book) And "no man can resist." Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  105

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Well sure. If people are stronger when we‘re fighting for our lives... (Why not demons?) He nods. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Greatness destroys.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I‘m just saying: sometimes a strength can be a weakness, know what I mean? INT. GRETTA’S APARTMENT. DAWN. Under another print of a floating angel: Hobbes, dressed sits on the floor by the couch, holding Sam‘s hand. The b barely awake.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Sam: I have to tell you something. Sam’s eyes open a little farther. He looks at Hobbes. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: My father.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I know. Hobbes looks in his eyes, sees he does know. Hobbes squeezes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Also...I have to go away. You’re going to stay with Gretta. Sam looks past Hobbes, to where Gretta stands in her door in her pajamas. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  106

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I want you to know: Whatever people say about me, and whatever I do... I'm doing it for you, okay?, because I love you. Sam looks up at him. Blankly for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m going to go back to sleep. {closes his eyes) And when I wake up, everything’s going to be better again. This almost breaks Hobbes’ heart. Gretta sits: beside Hobbes, beside Sam.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (to her, indicating Sam) You sure it’s okay? (For him to stay here?) She nods. Not a casual consent.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You know what that means, don’t you? She looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You’re not "low profile" anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GRETTA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It‘s okay. (slightly ironic) I'm ready. He takes her hand, squeezes it. Looks at her -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: They don’t have wings. (off her look) You want to see one?, look in the mirror. She kisses his hand. Fervently. CAMERA MOVES IN on her fa She’s covering his hand with kisses. Like a silent movie And then slowly...his hand pulls away. She’s left alone.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  107 EXT. LUCIUS’ HOUSE. DAY. Suburban neighborhood. Gretta’s car pulls up, Hobbes honk Lucius bounces out of a modest split-level house. He wear pants, no shirt, no shoes. He glances around warily, hand Hobbes a smail paper bag. Hobbes slips him a wad of hundred dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Loosh: I know you think I’ve crossed over, I know you think you’re insane to do this, but I truly appreciate your trust. In his time, Lucius has heard a lot of similar horseshit addicts, killers, con-men: Lucius Yeah, yeah. Just be careful, huh? He turns away, and Hobbes drives off: INT. GRETTA’S CAR. DAY. Hobbes punches a number on the car phone. As it starts to ring, he removes the contents of Lucius’ paper bag and sl into his shirt pocket. JONESY’S VOICE Jonesy -

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Hey. JONESY’S VOICE Hey. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. I just want tell you: when the moment comes...the right time, the right place: you know it. JONESY‘S VOICE What place? Hobbes smiles slightly (Jonesy has taken the bait) and sa nothing. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  108

dialogues.speaker: JONESY'S VOICE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Where you goin’, Hobbes?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Nowhere. Literally. Gonna take a long drive, go someplace no-one‘1ll find me. sit by the water and think. (THE ACTION SLOWS DRAMATICALLY, down to eerie nanoseconds

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: You must be wondering: what's Hobbes doing? Doesn’t he know he’s giving it away? Doesn’t he realize “Azazel" will enter every cop on the force until he finds this out? Of course, that’s the idea. But I have to be careful. Very careful...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAL TIME AND ACTION RESUMES
dialogues.text: Hobbes still driving. JONESY’S VOICE Hey Hobbes, I gotta ask you something. Hobbes sees a POLICE CAR coming toward him... As calmly and naturally as he can, he pulls to the side o road.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Shoot. JONESY‘S VOICE We been partners a long time. The police car glides past. The COP looks casually in Hob direction. Hobbes uses the phone receiver to block his fa

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah, twelve plus. Hobbes looks in his rear-view mirror, watches the cop car continue...slowly...up the street...

dialogues.speaker: JONESY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: So. Is there something you wanna say? (Do you want to confess?} Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  109 Hobbes sees the cop car turn the corner, vanish from view Hobbes sighs relief, focusses on Jonesy’s question:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. You’re a good partner, Jonesy. JONESY’S VOICE (a smile in his tone) You too, Hobbes. See you, huh? I'll never see you.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Yeah. He hangs up, drives back out into traffic. cur TO: INT. CAR. NIGHT. Hobbes driving. His face is grim. HOLD this shot so that seems to pierce inside him and give a sense of time passa the long drive up there. Then he turns the wheel and we a EXT. MILANO’S HOUSE. NIGHT. As Hobbes turns in the long driveway, his headlights catc metal on a distant hill. Another car is hidden in the bus

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (blinks, mutters) You flew up, huh? He parks, gets out. He‘s got a FLASHLIGHT in one hand, car keys in the other. As he goes toward the house, he flicks the keys into the bushes. The action is so quick and minimal that someone a distance wouldn't read it. He walks up onto the porch, glances in the window: It's dark inside; no sign of anyone. Hobbes moves to one side of the door (in case someone com out), leans against the wall of the building, shouts out the darkness: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  1210

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Come on out! I know you're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At some distance from Hobbes. A spooky, menacing shot, th of a stalker: bushes in the foreground, Hobbes in the b.g

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What do you want now? Haven’t you had enough fun? (answering himself) Or is there something more? (CONT.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different angle, from the other side of the building so t realize: there are two people after him. Like the other s this one says: vicious killer.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What? Another test? Another torture? You got me to kill someone. You murdered my brother. What more do you want?! Maguire steps out into view.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I just want to bring you in. Hobbes turns to face Maguire.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: So it’s you. Wwa je-dow Nee  Shu-shay!

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: I know you've got a gun. Drop it.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: (moving toward Maguire) Or else what? You‘1l shoot me? That'd be too easy. Where’s the fun in that?

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: Just drop the gun, huh? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Do what he says, Hobbes. Hobbes whirls around. Sees Jonesy. Mutters:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Two of you? This doesn’t fit his plan. He looks back and forth betwee them, trying to decide which one is Azazel, and then focu on his partner:

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: {pained at the idea) Jonesy? (Are you Azazel?} Jonesy says nothing. The other men are on opposite sides of Hobbes, 40 yards a and so far: both of them are in character. Hobbes carefully takes out his gun, drops it, stalls for

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: I didn’t do it, guys. I didn’t do any of it.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: I know that, Hobbes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: We'd both like to believe that. But we have to bring you in. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: Why? Maguire blinks in astonishment, shoots Jonesy a look -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What if we came up here and he'd disappeared into the wilderness... and we drove his car into the lake, end of story? Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  112

dialogues.speaker: MAGUIRE
dialogues.text: What the fuck’re you talkin’, Jonesy? We came to bring in the son-of-a-bitch so he could stand trial. If he did it, fine. If he didn’t, even better. But it's not our job to decide that. Half beat.

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: You’re quite right, Mack. I don’t know what got into me. (steps forward) Sorry Hobbes. (raises his gun, aims:) I gotta put on the cuffs. Jonesy moves forward. Hobbes’ eyes are shifting; he’s trying to figure out how escape. And which - if either - of these men is the demon Jonesy stops 20 feet from Hobbes. Still aiming his pistol right at him, so Hobbes has no chance to run. An odd frozen moment. Why did Jonesy stop?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: You know, Maguire... Life is chock full of surprises. Jonesy moves his gun just five degrees - from Hobbes to Maguire. Maguire frowns. Jonesy shoots. A look of complete astonishment on Maguire’s face...and h falls dead. Hobbes is also stunned. Is this the real Jonesy orc the d

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Why‘d you do that?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (casually) Come on. I’m your partner. (gestures toward woods) Go on, you’re free. Run. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  113 Hobbes looks at the woods, then back at Jonesy. He isn’t If he runs and Jonesy is the demon, won't Jonesy shoot hi the back?

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Keep thinking, Hobbes. Hobbes‘ expression changes; he suspects -

dialogues.speaker: JONESY
dialogues.text: (nasty, amused) So. Now Jonesy’s fucked too. He just shot his boss. Hobbes dives through the closed window into Milano’s hous "Jonesy" laughs. He walks casually toward the house...

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: How ‘bout that, Hobbes? You're fucked, Jonesy’s fucked. One at a time, eh? That's how we get you. One by one... "Jonesy" moves around the house, glancing quickly in wind as if trying to draw Hobbes’ fire...

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: See the deal? (If) I kill you, it’s the final pathetic chapter in the life of another disgraced hero. You’re just one more piece-of-shit human scum. (CONT. ) 7 "Jonesy" comes to the kitchen door. Standing to one side, throws it open.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Or, turn it around! If I die, I'll enter you - and before you go down, I'll put 20 more murders on your tab! He jumps: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  114 INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. “Jonesy” hurtles into the kitchen, eyes dancing with anticipation: he loves this shit.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Do I have a preference? Huh? What‘s maximum fun? I think you can guess, can’t you?, what maximum fun is? His eyes have adjusted to the darkness. He sees no sign o Hobbes. Gun lowered, he steps from the kitchen into: INT. MILANO’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. He enters, looks around, sees nothing. Slowly he raises his pistol toward his own head...

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Sure you can. His gun moving slowly, inevitably, toward his temple...

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY", (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Maximum fun is... {with a big smile) I become you. Just before the barrel reaches his skull - Hobbes flies at him out of the darkness - They careen to the floor - oe They're wrestling over Jonesy’s pistol. Varying shades of blackness, a few streaks of slashing moonlight. Their bod entwined, grappling. Visually: it feels like we're watchi something mythic.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What do you want? My heart? Soul? You'll never get ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: Fuck you, and fuck your heart, and fuck your soul. And that's a promise. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  115 Is "Jonesy" weakening...or is it intentional: the pistol pointed at his head. But Hobbes does not fire. Why? He keeps pushing the point the gun lower, lower...till it’s aimed at "Jonesy’s" ches A wrenching burst of energy. The men fly apart as the gun off - Silence. We can’t tell who was hit. Both bodies lie immob in the darkness. We HEAR "Jonesy" laugh. He‘s on the ground. Bleeding. Hobbes appears over him.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: (pained, playful) Eww, you got me, Hobbes. But isn’t that just ego?, huh?, to want to kill me yourself? What difference’s it make?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Not much. {CONT.) Hobbes takes a cigarette pack from his shirt pocket. Knoc one out, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But sometimes little things are important. ‘Sides, I want to talk. (puffs on cigarette) I think you were right: what Reese said? Milano was just like me. And he was trying to do just what I am. That’s why he bought this place, seven miles from nowhere... (another puff) But you didn't get it, did you? He didn't quite pull it off, so you didn’t get it. “ JONESY" Get what?

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: You didn't get it with him, and you still don’t get it with me. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  116

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: I don’t get it, and I don’t give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Don‘t you? Open your eyes, Azazel. Look around sometime. The way Hobbes says this is creepy, as though he’s won. F the first time in any human body, Azazel (as "Jonesy") lo nervous. His eyes scan the room...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Don't you see anything...different? "Jonesy’s" eyes come back to Hobbes, puffing away. "Jonesy" stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: (frowns) You don’t.... He stops talking, overcome by a wave of pain. Hobbes smiles casually, takes another puff.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: What‘d you say?

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: I said...you don’t... (talking with great difficulty) you don’t smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobbes smiles again, takes an even bigger draw, a long an heavy draw, pulling the smoke down into his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: That's right, Jonesy. I don’t. A horrible look of realization coming onto "Jonesy’s" fac

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: ‘Cause cigarettes kill.

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Especially: cigarettes laced with poison. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  117

dialogues.speaker: "JONESY"
dialogues.text: Noooooo! He spins, writhes, his body contorting, his eyes rolling

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Ever hear of a "scorched earth" policy? An army destroys its own country before the enemy invades. “Jonesy’s" body clenches... He glares at Hobbes...

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Seven miles from nowhere. You got no place to go but me. "Jonesy" starts to shake...harder, harder.

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: Come on, Azazel. Enter me, and we die together. Suddenly "Jonesy" has a huge horrifying spasm - And stops. Completely. Dead. OVERHEAD SHOT, TIGHT ON "JONESY". ALL SOUND CEASES. The CAMERA floats up slowly...moves over Hobbes... Hobbes stares down at Jonesy’s body... ON HIS FACE as he waits for the demon... Very softly, almost inaudible, saying goodbye to this wor

dialogues.speaker: HOBBES
dialogues.text: God bless you, Gretta. God bless you, Sam. He closes his eyes. His face starts to sweat. We sense the invisible battle t enter Hobbes. Very subtly: his breathing becomes harder, more intense. takes another drag on the cigarette...frowns...winces...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE OVERHEAD CAMERA. IT HOVERS...HOVERS...AND GOE
dialogues.text: Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  118 SWOOPING DOWN VIOLENTLY ONTO HOBBES’ FACE - He yanks the cigarette from his mouth, hurls it across th room - His face hard, enraged. "Hobbes" is now Azazel. He staggers out the door. Beside the door we see: his cigarette has landed on some scattered papers - EXT. MILANO’S HOUSE. MOONLIGHT. "Hobbes" flies out onto the porch, looks at the car in th driveway, pats his pants pocket - and then remembers. Cur Heads for the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE OUTSET OF THE MOVIE. "“HOBBES" STAGGERS FORWARD, SEARCHES THE BUSHES FOR THE CAR KEYS AS HE MUTTERS "God d God damn, God damn!", FINDS THE KEYS, THEN TRIES WITHOUT SUCCESS TO MOVE AWAY FROM THAT SPOT. Under this:)

dialogues.speaker: "HOBBES", (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Like I said at the start. I was beaten. Outsmarted. Poisoned. (snide, outraged} By John Hobbes. (CONT. } At this moment we realize, with a horrifying chill: this has_b d not by Hobbes he demon Azazel occupying Hobbes’ body.

dialogues.speaker: "HOBBES"
dialogues.text: He'd thought of everything. Even throwing away his keys ‘cause he saw I‘d parked far away so I’d want to use his car. His body crashes to the ground. Falling onto his back. Hi hand moves to his chest -

dialogues.speaker: "HOBBES", (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Can you imagine what it feels like to be alive for thousands of years and then actually die ‘cause some self-righteous Chicago cop decides he is going to save the fucking world                         Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  119 His eyes flicker. He's fading. And something else is happening too: his voice is changing...becoming deeper, raspier, full of air... The "natural voice" of the demon coming through...

dialogues.speaker: "HOBBES" /AZAZEL, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Thank God. Thank God there are other demons. We will prevail. He dies. Silence. Everything still and beautiful in the moonlight. Hold. The CAMERA DRAWS SLOWLY BACK FOR THE END OF THE FILM. ..C music starts...and happy music too. The audience must fee sense of real satisfaction: Hobbes (the real Hobbes) has With his "scorched earth" maneuver, Hobbes has killed "Ho killed the demon. We pull back farther, farther...and as if to cement our r "THE END" appears on the screen. The instant these word appear there is a HORRIBLE NOISE - The words are wrenched away - Something’s moving in the moonlight. A tail flickering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAT YOWLING! Hair up on end, arching its back: Possesse the demon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cat slowly turns...TOWARD THE CAMERA. And winks.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZEL, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: {playful) Fooled you. The Cat sits, licks its paws contentedly... Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www  “120

dialogues.speaker: AZAZEL, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember? I said I was going to tell you about "the time I almost died." Behind the Cat: light is flickering...a red glow... Milan house is going up in flames, providing a spectacular back to the Demonized Cat. The Cat looks over at Hobbes’ body, at the burning house.

dialogues.speaker: AZAZEL, (V.O., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: I better get moving. I have a long way to go. (CONT.} The Cat heads up the road. Trotting at a steady pace...

dialogues.speaker: AZAZEL, (V.O0., NARRATION)
dialogues.text: At least seven miles. The Cat's figure gradually disappears into the night...

dialogues.speaker: AZAZEL
dialogues.text: (slightly mocking) See you around. The Cat vanishes. Only darkness. END CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: POSSIBLE SEQUENCE UNDER TITLES
dialogues.text: The cat disappears into darkness. The darkness intensifie becomes BLACK. Then the black turns mottled, gray, grayer we're seeing something but we can’t tell what it is. Grad more definition appears. We’re on a city street. People a moving. Lots of people. Walking: some casually, some in a hurry. And idly, casually, without even knowing what they doing: they’re touching one another. Scanned and converted to PDF by SCREENTALK Magazine - www
